 ABIY S. HIRUYE

 EDUCATION
_____________________________________________________________________________
1990-1998 MD, jimma Institute of Health Sciences( currently Jimma University), Ethiopia
2009-2011, Masters in Public Health, Haramaya University, Ethiopia

EMPLOYMENT
_____________________________________________________________________________

1998-2000, Metekel Hospital, Benshangul Gumuz region, Ethiopia
2000-2001, Blue Nile Higher Clinic
2001-2005, Israel Embassy Medical Center
2005-2008, Medan ACTS Health & HIV program
2009-2010, Children Home society & Family Services      
2010-present, Ethiopian Medical Association

At various capacities: Executive Director(present) , coordinator  health projects , BCC Project officer- M & E officer (2005-2008), Medical Director (2001-2005), General Practitioner (1998-2001)

ADDITIONAL RESPONSIBILITIES

1.	Steering committee member Ethiopian Hospital Alliance for Quality 2012-13
2.	National Continuing Professional Development working group member
3.	Working group In-service Training Guideline development.
4.	Served in the Scientific review, schedules preparation and exhibition coordinating  sub-committee  of 2014 International Family Planning conference in Addis Ababa


TRAINING & WORKSHOPS _____________________________________________________________________________

1.	Various HIV AIDS related trainings :Educational methods & messages, Coverage strategies & M&E in ABC program, BCC strategy Design for PEPFAR partners, Motivational interview, Quality improvement  in ABC
2.	PMTCT action research Part I, July 2006,  Nairobi, PMTCT Action research phase II, Nairobi, September 2006,  and PMTCT Action research, Phase III , Nairobi, October 7-11, 2007, Tear Fund UK
3.	Monitoring and Evaluation of Heath, population and Nutrition programs, July-August 2008, Measure Evaluation- Addis Ababa University, EPHA
4.	International conference on AIDS & Sexually Transmitted infections in Africa( ICASA), Dakar Senegal, December 2008
5.	Electronic Short Course on Antiretroviral Treatment (e-SCART) ,May-July 2009, from University of Antwerp ,Belgium  
6.	Online Education Facilitation Certificate from University of Antwerp, 2011
7.	Management Development Institute from 8-15 April, 2012, Kenya, UCLA-AMREF 
8.	Effective Teaching and Course Design and Delivery 24 July-August 2, 2013.Jhpiego
9.	Financial Management by CRS, September 2013, Nairobi.
10.	Electronic Continuing Professional Development delivery training , Dec 16-20, 2013, Jhpiego Ethiopia
11.	Experience sharing visit to Kenya in July 2014 and  to Uganda Sep 2014 on Health system issues 
 

CONSULTANCY  _____________________________________________________________________________

1.	Organizational performance review, Norwegian Bible Society & its partners HIV AIDS program- commissioned by NORAD.
I was the part of the team of three consultants, two international and myself as local consultant who did the review and the write up. I was involved in the interview and writing final report to NORAD.
2.	Nine month joint review of the 2008 & 2009 planning of the national multi-sectoral HIV AIDS response- Federal HAPCO( National HIV AIDS prevention & control office -UNAIDS Country office -writing the proceedings -May 2009)
I was contracted  as consultant by UNAIDS to write the proceedings for the joint review . My role was to synthesize a report and submitted to the National HIV AIDS Prevention and control office.

column108: Alessandra Casanova Guedes , MSc, MA 5415 Uppingham Street, Chevy Chase, MD 20815 USA | +1 202 288 8998 alessandra.casanova.guedes@gmail.com Highly regarded global leader in the field of preventing violence against children and violence against women, with more than 20 years’ experience in public health and international development. Established author of prominent research and normative guidance on violence, with a strong track record of positively influencing national and international policy and programs. Excellent ability to analyze data, synthesize evidence, and communicate key findings to help decision makers develop technically-sound policies and programs. Skilled negotiator and leader with proven ability to manage and work effectively with professionals from diverse cultures and backgrounds. Exceptional written and oral communication skills. Fluent in English, Portuguese and Spanish. P R O F E S S I O N A L E X P E R I E N C E Regional Advisor, Family Violence October 2009 to present Pan American Health Organization / World Health Organization Regional Office for the Americas (PAHO/WHO), Washington D.C. Provide strategic, technical and programmatic leadership in the areas of violence against children and violence against women prevention and response at the global level and within the Region of the Americas. Work with regional, national, and local authorities to support the development, implementation and evaluation of public policies, programs, and normative guidance aimed at preventing and responding to violence against children and violence against women. Select accomplishments: • Led the development of the first Regional Strategy and Plan of Action to Strengthen the Health System Response to Violence against Women in the Americas approved unanimously in October 2015 by Ministers of Health from 38 countries. With this highly successful effort, PAHO/WHO became the first WHO Region to have a document guiding its response to violence approved by its highest governing body. • Envisioned, fundraised for and led the research team that carried out the first-ever comparative analysis of nationally representative data on violence against women for the Latin America and the Caribbean Regions. • Organize and lead conferences, expert meetings and capacity building efforts to strengthen violence prevention and response and set agenda and strategic goals, thereby reaching hundreds of Government officials and members of civil society organizations a oss the Americas and beyond. • Participate in the advisory committees responsible for developing: the first WHO policy and clinical guidelines for responding to intimate partner and sexual violence against women, the first WHO policy and clinical guidelines for child maltreatment (ongoing), Pan Canadian public health guidance for responding to children exposed to intimate partner violence (ongoing). • Lead international efforts to integrate attention to violence within diverse platforms and agendas, including early childhood development, child health, mental health, substance use prevention and others. • Successfully managed a team of professionals to implement a multi-country effort to improve efforts to prevent violence against children and violence against women in Central America. • Provide expert guidance to key violence initiatives, including the Sexual Violence Research Initiative (SVRI / co-chair), Together for Girls, Preventing Violence A oss the Lifespan (PreVAIL), and others. • Establish and manage successful collaborative relationships with other UN agencies (UNICEF, UN Women, etc.) and academic and research column108: I am Adugnaw Berhane from Ethiopia.I have graduated in year 2003, from Debub University and got a Bachelor Degree in Public Health, Masters of Public Health by the year 2008 from Jimma University, and PhD in Public Health by the year 2016 from Addis Ababa University, Ethiopia. Since graduated, I have been working as a clinician and Health Center Head and Coordinator of District HIV/AIDS prevention and Control Office for about 3 years, as lecturer in Keamed Medical for 2 years, as Dean and instructor at the College of Health Sciences in Debre Berhan University for 7 years which makes me a total of more than 12 years work experience. I have research experience on communicable and noncommunicable diseases, clinical and public health problems, Maternal and child health, mental health, substance abuse, injuries and risk factors etc.  I am skilled softwares for data analysis like EPInfo & SPSS, STATA for Quantitative data analysis and Open code software for qualitative data analysis.

column108:
BIANCA CALABRIA
National Centre for Epidemiology and Population Health
Australian National University
62 Mills Road, Acton, ACT, 2601
+61 2 6125 7175
bianca.calabria@anu.edu.au

EDUCATION
National Drug and Alcohol Research Centre (NDARC), UNSW, NSW, Australia
Doctor of Philosophy (PhD), Creating partnerships between researchers, health care providers and Indigenous Australians to improve Indigenous health: a demonstration model
Thesis by publication submitted 30 August 2013, conferred 19 March 2014
Thesis includes six publications

Macquarie University, NSW, Australia
Honours Degree of Bachelor of Psychology (BPsych(Hons))
Completed November 2007, conferred 23 April 2008

AWARDS
NDARC Jen McLaren Research Award, 2013
This awards the most productive non-academic staff member at NDARC (staff of 130) in terms of publications and grants
UNSW Faculty of Medicine Deans List, 2012
This competitive award acknowledges the achievements of young researchers with the potential to become career scientists
NDARC Annual Symposium Outstanding Poster Award, 2011
This award is presented to the two posters of the highest quality at the Symposium

GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS
NDARC PhD scholarship, 2010  2013
Macquarie University internet-based research grant, 2007

SUPERVISION
I am currently joint primary supervisor of a PhD student who is investigating community driven intervention development aimed at reducing alcohol-related injuries and violence among Aboriginal Australians.

CURRENT EMPLOYMENT
National Centre for Epidemiology and Population Health, Australian National University, ACT, Australia
Research Fellow, 2015  present 
I am currently employed to work on a NHMRC Partnership Project with a focus on investigating inequalities in cardiovascular disease among Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians. 

EMPLOYMENT HISTORY
NDARC, UNSW, NSW, Australia
Research Officer, 2007  2015
I project managed a funded project aiming to reduce alcohol-related injuries and violence among Aboriginal people in rural New South Wales through community lead interventions. This involved working with a locally based steering committee to find a balance between rigorous research methods and intervention implementation in a real world setting. I have also worked on a project that tailored and evaluated two evidence-based programs aimed at reducing drug- and alcohol-related harms among Aboriginal Australians in rural NSW. Other research projects I have been involved in are: ACE Alcohol Indigenous study; Alcohol Action in Rural Communities study; the Global Burden of Disease 2010 study; the Victorian Adolescent Health Cohort study; and the Cannabis Potency and Contamination study.  My roles have included writing publications and reports, systematic literature searches, data analysis, and leadership through training, supervising and co-ordinating students, research staff and health services staff involved in collaborative research. I was on leave from this role from February 2012 to August 2012, and from January 2014 to January 2015.

Relationships Australia, NSW, Australia
Research Officer, 2008
I worked on a casual basis with researchers to plan an evaluation of an intervention for children who live in high risk households for domestic violence. My main duties were to conduct literature searches and also to work with the team of researchers to develop the study methodology.

PUBLICATIONS, REPORTS AND PRESENTATIONS
Peer reviewed publications

Medical University MD 2009 Community Medicine A. Personal Statement. I have been a faculty member in the Department of Community Health since completion of my post graduate degree in 2009. During these years I have been a physician cum obstetrician, academic teacher, researcher and co in-charge of the primary health care program of the department and the heath educational team. As a physician, I have been involved mainly in the care of pregnant women, children, and those suffering from non-communicable diseases. I have held various roles in research projects, including training the field workers, organizing survey implementation, data analysis, and paper preparation. BIOGRAPHICAL SKETCH


NAME
Duncan, Bruce Bartholow	POSITION TITLE
Full Professor

	
EDUCATION/TRAINING  
INSTITUTION AND LOCATION	       DEGREE 	MM/YY	FIELD OF STUDY
Williams College, Williamstown, Mass.	BA	1971	Economics
Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD	MD	1979	Medicine
North Carolina Memorial Hospital 	(Res)	1983	Peds (R1), Intern Med, Prev Med 

Federal Univ. Rio Grande do Sul  	PhD	1991	Epidemiology
			

A. Personal Statement
I am an internist and an epidemiologist, and have published over 180 peer reviewed articles, as well as dozens of book chapters and a major Brazilian textbook. My works, according to Google Scholar, have been cited 14495 times, and my H-index is 62, Much of my scientific production has been as an investigator of the ARIC Study, with work done both in the United States and in Brazil. My major areas of interest have been diabetes and, secondarily, other cardiovascular risk factors. I trained through medical school and the master´s level in the United States and have, since 1983, worked primarily on research and training aimed at providing an evidence base and competence for improving primary care and for dealing with chronic non-communicable diseases, especially diabetes, in Brazil.

B. Positions and Honors

column108:
Curriculum Vitae

Date of Revision:  07/17/2015

Name:  Brian J. Biroscak, PhD, MS, MA

Topic Areas of Expertise: Brian Biroscak is Assistant Professor in the Department of Emergency Medicine at Yale University. His line of research is focused by a social justice perspective and positioned to make him a leader in violence and injury prevention through knowledge generation, utilization, and dissemination. 
In regard to knowledge generation, Prof. Biroscak has worked in the area of emergency medicine research since November 2008. He considers emergency medicine to be an integral part of public healtha field in which he has extensive experience dating back to the year 2000. Prof. Biroscak contributes to violence and injury prevention through public health-surveillance and -research activities. He also has a strong research interest in system dynamics modeling, which utilizes feedback insights and computer simulation to hypothesize, test, and refine explanations of systems change. 
Prof. Biroscak uses those research insights to guide knowledge utilization efforts for violence and injury prevention, which can reduce the burden of such patients on emergency medicine practitioners as well as contribute to population health improvement. As social improvement ultimately boils down to influencing the behavior of individuals (e.g., violence perpetrators, community members, policymakers), Prof. Biroscaks expertise in social marketing, which integrates commercial marketing with other approaches to influence behaviors that benefit individuals and the greater social good, is particularly valuable. 
Prof. Biroscak shares his lessons learned from research and intervention work through a variety of knowledge dissemination activities. He presents his work in oral and written forms through scientific presentations and publications. He has instructed a number of undergraduate and graduate students. Prof. Biroscak serves on several conference planning committees. As Director of Evaluation for the CDC-funded Florida Prevention Research Center at the University of South Florida, he works to increase the research and development capacity of their faculty and staff. Concurrently, he seeks to do the same as Director of Research for the Section of Research in the Department of Emergency Medicine at Yale University.

 Personal Information:

Marital Status		Married 
Nationality 		Sudanese 
Date of Birth 		Jan .1952  Sudan 

1	Public health professional with extensive national, regional and international health development experiences. Served as senior  national advisor to the government in capacity of minister, undersecretary and director of planning. Had a leading role in health system reform including National Health Strategy (25 Year Strategy, 5 Year Health Strategy , National Health Policy, National Policy for Private Medical Practice, National Policy for Health in Emergencies , National Policy for Health in Emergencies and decentralization polices .As chairman of CCM and Gavi committee had a leading role in planning and implantation oversight of Global fund and Gavi programs.
2	 Assisted in scaling up of both national health programs and health education institutions. Specific areas include launching national campaign to promote the image of public health professions. Accordingly, assisted in establishment of academy of health sciences and public health institute aimed at rapidly boosting the production of health workers, particularly in underserved and conflict-affected areas. 

Key accomplishments

1.	Leadership role and change agent in the area of evidence-based policy formation via consensus building and creation of health policy advisory forum with participation of senior health officials
2.	Initiated and implemented an innovative forum for effective stakeholder's coordination, including collaboration with UN agencies.
3.	Leadership role in Joint Assessment Mission carried out with the World bank and other international agencies to define priority areas in post-conflict locations. Served as key member in negotiation with multiple donors for rapid and long-term recovery of the health sector.
4.	Leadership role in tackling infectious diseases and emerging epidemics by establishing national surveillance system with rapid mobilization and field deployment of experts
5.	Development of national policies and strategic plans for the health workforce
6.	Leadership role in development of system for continuous professional development and establishing centre for that with other stakeholders
7.	Assisted in the development, implementation of national system for monitoring & evaluation, including integrated approach to vertical and horizontal programs.

column108:
Alice M. Raymond
Senior Health Financing Associate in Cameroon
MPH Global Health and Development - 4 years experience
Bastos, Yaoundé, Cameroon
araymond@clintonhealthaccess.org
(+237) 678 954 184
EDUCATION 
Oct 13 - Sep 14 Master of Public Health - Global Health and Development, with honours at Imperial College School of Medicine, London, UK.
• Modules: global health challenges and governance, health economics, health system policy &
financing, statistics, epidemiology, health information and management.
Nov 13 - May 14 Health System Development course at WHO Collaborating Center for Public Health, London, UK.
• Professional development training in health management including financing, strategic planning, advocacy, policy, information systems and human resources.
Sep 08 - Nov 11 Engineering degree (MSc level) in Biomedical sciences, with honours at Ecole Supérieure d’Ingénieur de Luminy (School of advanced studies in engineering), Marseille, France.
• Modules: mi
obiology, biochemistry, drug development and production, virology, immunology,
economy and finance, law and management.
WORK EXPERIENCE
Sep 14 - Present Health financing associate (acting as program manager for 8 months) at Clinton Health Access Initiative, Yaoundé, Cameroon.
• Lead technical assistant in the elaboration of the National Health Financing Strategy.
• Central support to the Universal Health Coverage process (OASIS study, definition of benefit
package and architecture of the future national scheme, etc.)
• Development of the financing and health system strengthening modules of the Health Sector
Strategy 2016-2027 and the National Health Development Plan 2016-2020
• Costing of the Health Sector Strategy and National Health Development Plan (One Health) and the National Immunisation Strategic Plan (activity-based)
Mar 14 - Nov 14 Consultant research analyst for MetaVirology LTD, London, UK.
• Statistical analysis of clinical trials and cohort studies in HIV/AIDS field for Chelsea and Westminster Hospital (MITOC, SSAT 044, and SSAT 049 studies)
• Cost analysis of SINGLE study (DTG+ABC/3TC versus EFV/TDF/FTC) for switch in HIV/AIDS
treatment regimen in the UK.
• Literature review on HIV dual therapy and single tablet regimens
• Analysis of the level of implementation of the 90-90-90 UNAIDS target in developing countries
May 14 - Sep 14 Research assistant at Imperial College Center for Health Policy, London, UK.
• Qualitative analysis of the role of Community Health Worker and Malaria prevention methods in Mali and Burkina Faso.
• Market analysis for Community Health Worker services based on a supply, demand and
performance model.
Nov 11 - Aug 13 Research associate in Theodora Hatziioannou’s laboratory, Aaron Diamond AIDS Research Center, New York, USA.
• Genetic adaptation of HIV to be pathogenic in pigtail macaques.
• Study of the polymorphism of restrictions factors in pigtail macaques: extraction, cloning and functional analysis.
Feb 11 - Aug 11 Research assistant in Theodora Hatziioannou’s laboratory, Aaron Diamond AIDS Research Center, New York, USA.
• Study of interactions between host cell restriction factors and SIV/HIV viral proteins in macaques.
• Initial identification of restriction factors variants from pigtail macaques.
PUBLICATIONS - CONFERENCES
• Can the UNAIDS 90-90-90 target be reached? Analysis of national level HIV treatment cascades. Raymond A, Levy J, Pozniak A, Vernazza P, Kohler P, Ford N, Hill A. IAS Conference on pathogenesis, treatment and prevention Vancouver 2015, BMJ Global Health April 2016.
• CD4 polymorphisms in response to sHIVs introduction in pigtail and rhesus macaques. Hatziioannou T, Bitzegeio J, Raymond A, Rodriguez A, Blanco-Melo D, and Bieniasz PD. Submitted to Cell H&M in March 2015.
• Large disparity in HIV treatment cascades between eight European and high-income countries – analysis of break points. Raymond A, Hill A, Pozniak A. November 2014, Journal Int. AIDS Society, Vol 17:19507, HIV Drug Therapy Glasgow 2014, received the Junior Researcher Award.
• HIV-1 induced AIDS in monkeys. Hatziioannou T, Del Prete G, Keele B, Estes J, Bitzegeio J, Raymond A, Rodriguez A, McNatt M, Mac Trubey C, Smedley J, Piatak Jr. M, KewalRamani V, Lifson JD and Bieniasz PD. June 2014, Science, Vol 344:6189.
• Higher antiretroviral treatment coverage is associated with lower adult HIV infection rates: analysis of 51 low and middle-income countries. Hill A, Pozniak A, Raymond A, Heath K, Ford N, World AIDS 2014. 
COMMUNITY AND CHARITY INVOLVEMENT
Mar 15 - Present Active member of Harmonisation for Health in Africa Community of Practice Health systems planning and budgeting, Health service delivery, and Financial access to care
Feb 13 - Present UN online volunteer Last mission completed in 2014 for Volunteer Partnership for West Africa: translation of the website from English to French.
Feb 14 - Sept 14 Homecare worker volunteer Part-time carer for Monica Elston, 94 years old.
May 12 - May 13 AIDS Walk volunteer: Creator of the Aaron Diamond AIDS Walk New York Team Creation and management of the 11-walkers team and fundraising: $3,015 raised in total 
MISCELLANEOUS
Computer skills: High proficiency in Excel, PowerPoint, Word, One Health Tool, proficiency in STATA, NVivo, notions in C & R.
Languages: French: native speaker. English: fluent (IELTS score: 8.0). Spanish: conversational.
REFERENCES
Available upon request
Hobbies: Travelling, art-house cinema, yoga, swing and contemporary dance.

column108:
Bolanle Feyisayo Banigbe. MD, MPH
52b, 4th Avenue, Gwarimpa. Abuja, Nigeria
baluko@apin.org.ng, bbanigbe@gmail.com
+234-8037540086
I.	EDUCATION

	Master of Public Health (with distinction). 
University of Leeds, United Kingdom.  September 2006.  

	Post Graduate Diploma in Health Systems Management (External Degree).
 London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, United Kingdom. June 2005

	Bachelor of Medicine and Surgery (MBBS). 
University of Ibadan, Nigeria. October 2002

II.	AWARD
The John Griffith prize for distinctive work, University of Leeds, UK. September, 2006

III.	WORK AND RESEARCH EXPERIENCE 

In the last 7 years, I have worked for AIDS Prevention Initiative in Nigeria (APIN); APIN was established as a project of the Harvard School of Public Health (HSPH) in 2000 with a grant from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, focusing on HIV prevention including PMTCT in selected states of Nigeria. In 2003, it became a sub- contractor to HSPH on its PEPFAR Track 1.0 grant to provide comprehensive ART services in Nigeria. In 2007, it was incorporated as a legal entity in Nigeria and has since been implementing comprehensive HIV care and treatment programmes with funding from PEPFAR through the US Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in Nigeria and the Global Fund. Cumulatively, APIN has provided care and treatment services to about  150,000 HIV infected children and adults in over 100 health facilities across 13 states of Nigeria and it implements one of the most robust electronic patient record management system for HIV care in Nigeria.

	January 2014 till date:

Senior Technical Advisor, Quality Assurance and Quality Improvement
AIDS Prevention Initiative in Nigeria (APIN)
I am responsible for the design of clinical and programme Quality Management (QM) policies and systems. I also contribute to clinical and programme management policy development APIN wide based on findings from quality management reports and site supervisory visits. I also represent my organization on the Federal Ministry of Health (FMOH) led national Quality Improvement (QI) task team which is responsible for developing a national HIV QI strategy and spreading the QI culture in Nigeria. I am also responsible for designing and implementing QI trainings at the programme office and supported clinics based on training needs assessments and I work with the Plateau State Ministry of Health HIV QI management team to build their capacity to lead state wide HIV QI activities.

I also coordinate the organizations research efforts by supporting proposal development, linking programme officers to available resources and people with similar interests and liaising with external collaborators. My most important current research activity is summarised below:

Title of research project:  Patient and health system factors associated with Loss To Follow Up (LTFU) and unplanned care interruption in HIV care.
Role on project: In- country team lead
Project description:  This 5 year study (January 2013- December 2017) funded by NIH is a K23 career development grant awarded to Dr Aimalohi Ahonkhai of Massachusetts General Hospital Boston. The project aims to study the four domains of health system processes that might affect patient adherence with chronic HIV care: accessibility, affordability, acceptability, and availability. It is also examining decisional conflict at the patient level and its association with LTFU and care interruption and will use the findings to pilot a home-based HIV care intervention (or any other intervention supported by data from early phases of the study) designed to address important health system processes and sources of patient conflict to reduce LTFU and unplanned care interruption.
Responsibilities on the team:
o	Liaison between the study team and ethical review boards of study clinics and corresponding author on prospective study. I also monitor compliance with ethical standards during data abstraction, patient enrollment and follow up 
o	Liaison between study team and in-country grants and finance departments
o	Programmatic advise during proposal development 
o	Mapping of available programme data and data sources to study questions
o	Contribute to abstract/manuscript writing





 Publications 

1.	Seema Thakore Meloni, Charlotte Chang, Beth Chaplin, Holly Rawizza, Oluwatoyin Jolayemi, Bolanle Banigbe, Prosper Okonkwo, and Phyllis Kanki. Time-Dependent Predictors of Loss to Follow-Up in a Large HIV Treatment Cohort in Nigeria. Open Forum Infectious Diseases.  July 2014

2.	Prosper Okonkwo, Atiene Sagay, Patricia Agaba, Stephen Yohanna, Oche Agbaji, Godwin Imade, Bolanle Banigbe, Juliet Adeola, Tinuade Oyebode, John Idoko, and Phyllis Kanki. Treatment Outcomes in a Decentralized Antiretroviral Therapy Program: A Comparison of Two Levels of Care in North Central Nigeria. AIDS Research and Treatment. June 2014 

3.	Chaplin B, Meloni S, Eisen G, Jolayemi T, Banigbe B, Adeola J, Wen C, Reyes-Nieva H, Chang C, Okonkwo P Kanki P, Scale-up of networked HIV treatment in Nigeria: Creation of an integrated electronic medical records system. Int J Med Inform. 2014; DOI: 10.1016/j.ijmedinf.2014.09.006.


Conference Posters

2014	Immune, Virologic and Adherence Measures as Time-Dependent Predictors of Loss to Follow-Up:  Seema Thakore Meloni, Charlotte Chang, Doug Hoi Cheung, Beth Chaplin, Holly Rawizza, Oluwatoyin Jolayemi, Bolanle Banigbe, Prosper Okonkwo, Phyllis Kanki	CROI
2013	Quality of Care Provided to HIV Positive Children at Facilities without Paediatricians in an HIV Programme in Nigeria. Banigbe Bolanle, Ahmed Isah, Adu Rosemary, Olaniran Abimbola, Meloni Seema, Okonkwo Prosper.	APIN Scientific Conference. Abuja, Nigeria
2011	Continuous Quality Improvement as a strategy for strengthening Health Systems: Bolanle Banigbe, Toyin Jolayemi, Ernest Ekong, Prosper Okonkwo	Association of Public Health Physicians of Nigeria Annual Conference. Abuja , Nigeria


	September 2011- December 2013
Senior Programme Specialist, Strategic Information (SI), APIN

I coordinated the activities of the SI department consisting of the Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E), database management and quality assurance units; ensuring that the department provided APIN with evidence for driving programming including clinical patient care, laboratory services and financial management and supported partner HIV treatment sites to set up and maintain systems for electronic data capture, reporting and data use. As part of the organizations health systems strengthening activities, I managed the process that supported 3 states to conduct their first ever M&E systems assessment using the UNAIDS 12 component tool.  I also led the team that carried out the grant close out activities for the organizations first five year PEPFAR grant 


	May 2009  August  2011
Quality Assurance Coordinator (APIN)

I set up the organizations quality assurance unit and my major responsibility was to drive quality improvement programmes with a view to achieve best practice performance levels and implementation of evidence based practices in caring for HIV infected patients and their families at supported HIV clinics. I achieved this by developing a quality assurance strategy for the organization and supporting all clinical sites to establish site led QI Committees. I also developed and implemented a QI coaching framework for over 40 clinical sites supported by APIN. 

	February 2007 to April 2009
 Monitoring and Evaluation Coordinator, APIN

My major responsibility was to strengthen routine M&E systems in the programme office and at supported HIV clinics. I achieved this by developing M&E guidelines as a strategy for improving the quality of the data available for patient management and programme reporting. I also developed the programmes first data quality audit protocol, and gained extensive experience of conducting data quality audits at service delivery points. I represented APIN on the national HIV QI pilot project implemented by PEPFAR, FMOH and HIVQual New York and developed a successful proposal to establish a quality assurance unit separate from M&E in the organization.

	February 2005- August 2005.   
Tree Shade Associates, Makurdi, Nigeria
Trainee Health and Social development Consultant
I participated in the implementation of a DFID supported multi-component health systems rapid assessment and systems strengthening initiative for primary and secondary health care facilities in Ekiti State.
 

	February 2004-January 2005
Medical officer, Civil Service Hospital, Ilorin
Employer:  Kwara State Ministry of Health , Nigeria
My responsibilities were general medical practice (in-patient and out -patient care) and tutorial support to 5th year medical students of the University of Ilorin Teaching Hospital

	January 2003- January 2004. 
House Officer (Intern). University College Hospital, Ibadan, Nigeria
My responsibilities were in- patient and outpatient care in the departments of Internal Medicine, Surgery, Paediatrics and Obstetrics and Gynaecology.

Research activities:

Research interests:
I am primarily interested in insecticide resistance and its classic, biochemical and molecular mechanisms in different arthropod pests including mosquitoes, roaches, ticks and etc.

Current research projects:

1)	Malaria vector control and insecticide resistance.
2)	Funestic and ecologic studies of Culicidae with a focus on Aedes mosquitoes  in Mazandaran province 
3)	Funestic and ecologic studies of hard ticks in Mazandaran province and their susceptibility status and biochemical and molecular mechanisms of resistance to common acaricides 

4)	CCHF, seroepidemiology and the involvement of hard ticks in Nour, Mazandaran.


5)	Detection of polymorphisms of altered acetylcholine esterase gene in organophosphorous insecticide resistant Rhipicephalus bursa (Acari, Ixodidae) from Sari in 2013 using denaturing high performance liquid chromatography (DHPLC)

6)	Preparation, characterization and evaluation of permethrin and deltamethrin nanoparticles in vitro and in vivo 


7)	Study of the species belonging to the genus Paederus (causative agent of linear dermatitis) in Mazandaran sandy coastal areas
8)	Nano pesticides and their application in vector control and insecticide resistance management

column108: Abiola Ogunenika completed her medical school training at the Obafemi Awolowo College of Health Sciences, Olabisi Onabanjo University, Ago-Iwoye, Ogun state and qualified as a Medical Doctor in 2005. She has since been involved with health projects of various Governments and Non-Governmental Organisations in primary, secondary and tertiary care settings in Nigeria and abroad. Abiola served as medical officer with the USAID-Family Health International Global HIV/AIDS Initiative Nigeria (GHAIN) project under the National Youth Service Corps scheme in 2007. On completion of the youth service programme, she joined the international program of HARVARD-PEPFAR AIDS Prevention Initiative Nigeria (APIN) at the University College Hospital Ibadan. In 2010, Abiola Ogunenika was involved as a Primary Care physician with the Ministry of Health Primary Care program in Saudi Arabia focusing primarily on Prevention of Mother-to-Child transmission of HIV (PMTCT). Her strong interest to advance in knowledge of quality disease prevention and treatment programming made her proceed to the United Kingdom where she completed the British Association for Sexual Health & HIV (BASHH) Certificate Course in November 2012 becoming better equipped to provide technical and programmatic support for high quality programme implementation in the areas of ART, PMTCT and HIV care. Abiola Ogunenika is a Fellow of the PEPFAR Health Professional Fellowship Program of the PEPFAR-Management Sciences of Health’s course on leadership, management and sustainability of Public Health Programs and currently undergoing training as Fellow of the University of Washington’s Evans School of Public Policy & Governance International Program in Public Health Leadership (IPPHL) Dr. Ogunenika presently works with the Ondo State Ministry of Health at the Planning Research & Statistics Department and is involved with documenting operational challenges of the current challenging issues of health programs in her environment and ensuring usage of research findings to enact improvement and policy change. She also is the State Program Manager of the Saving One Million Lives (SOML) Program for Results (PforR), a Maternal Newborn and Child Nutrition Program initiative of the Federal Government of Nigeria supported by the World Bank designed to leverage States’ own efforts in delivery of maternal and child health services focusing on results to improve service delivery. Her duties involve working a oss multi-departmental health programs including Malaria, HIV, Family Planning, Immunization, Nutrition programs, their implementing agencies and all 3 tiers of government. SKILLS SUMMARY • Medical doctor with experience in healthcare and treatment policy programmes. • Excellent communication and interpersonal skills developed through interactions with clients, patients and colleagues in diverse work environments and through formal educational training • Effectively works as part of a team with other team members a oss disciplines and independently when necessary. • Eager to learn and willing to undertake additional training to enhance duties. • Involvement with NGOs, Community based programs & Charities • Operational Research skills. • Capable of accepting and following instructions in a safe and efficient manner. • International experience. • Flexible with regards to location, time and willing to travel. • Excellent English speaking, writing and reading abilities. • Proactive, organized and skilled in working within high pressure environments • IT literate and proficient in the use of Mi osoft application packages. PRIMARY MEDICAL QUALIFICATION October, 2005 - Obafemi Awolowo College of Health Sciences, Olabisi Onabanjo University, Ago-Iwoye, Ogun State, Nigeria Degree Earned: M.B.Ch., B (Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery) ADDITIONAL TRAINING May 2017- International Program in Public Health Leadership (IPPHL) Evans School of Public Policy & Governance University of Washington, Seattle USA Nov. 2014 - PEPFAR Health Professional Fellowship Program Obafemi Awolowo University Ile-Ife (OAU) / Management Sciences of Health (MSH), Nigeria Nov. 2012 - British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) course BASHH Certificate in Sexual Health & HIV United Kingdom PREVIOUS WORK EXPERIENCE 05/2010 to 04/2011 Kingdom of Saudi Arabia Ministry Of Health Al-Lithe Primary Health Care, Jeddah Region. Title: Primary Care Physician 02/2009 to 03/2010 Harvard - PEPFAR AIDS Prevention Initiative Nigeria University College Hospital, Ibadan, Nigeria Title: Medical Officer 10/2007 to 10/2008 Anambra State Ministry of Health Nigeria FHI-Global HIV/AIDS Initiative Nigeria Project Amaku General Hospital , Awka, Anambra, Nigeria. Title: Medical Officer 06/2006 - 12/2006 University College Hospital, Ibadan (Internship Training in Paediatrics, Obstetrics & Gynaecology) Title: House Officer 11/2005 - 05/2006 Olabisi Onabanjo University Teaching Hospitals (Internship Training in Medicine, Surgery) Title: House Officer ADDITIONAL EXPERIENCE 02/2007 – Till date Pro-Health International Free Health Care Projects in Nigeria Role: Volunteer Medic 10/2007 - 10/2008 Nigerian Christian Corpers’ Fellowship (NCCF) Anambra Chapter, Nigeria. Role: Community Mobilizer 10/2007 - 09/2008 National Reproductive Healths and HIV/AIDS Prevention Project Community Secondary school, Okpuno, Awka, Anambra State, Nigeria Role: Peer Educator Trainer HONORS AND AWARDS 02/2007 Award in Appreciation of Volunteer services- Pro- Health International 08/2008 Recommendation and Recognition for outstanding performance in care of PLWHAs- Office of the Honourable Commissioner of Health, Anambra . 03/2011 Recognition for key contributions to start up of a home based HIV care project in the Al-lith Community, Jeddah Region Saudi Arabia HIV/AIDS Program. MAIN LANGUAGE(S) English (Advanced Proficiency in speaking, reading and writing) & Yoruba (Native speaker) ADDITIONAL LANGUAGE Arabic (Basic)

column108:
Bereket Yakob has over nine years of experience working in public health sectors, consulting firms, civic organizations, communities and health facilities. He worked on various positions starting from clinical care provider at health center to senior national program coordination advisor for health system strengthening and HIV/AIDS prevention and control projects. He also worked as regional program coordiantion consultant for Amhara and SNNP regions. He also worked for JSI/ESHE project as Health System Performance Improvement Specialist and Systems Officer for USAID/IFHP in SNNPR. He initiated and participated on several program/project evaluations, mid-term and end-line assessments, and research activities in health systems, adherence to HIV/AIDS care, nutrition, maternal and child health programs, podoconiosis, risk factors for STIs and HIV, performance improvement, needs assessments and feasibility studies. I have demonistrated skills in conducting qualitative and quantitative research methods i.e. designing, data colletion, analysis, writing and presentation. He has demonistrated expereince in data processing, use of advanced stat program and presentation of data.  He is a public health specialist and currently a PhD candidate in public health at the University of KwaZulu Natal, Durban, South Africa.

column108:
AJAY TANDON
Global Practice on Health, Nutrition, and Population, World Bank
MSN MC 9-919, 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, DC 20433
E-Mail: atandon@worldbank.org, Phone: +1-202-473-6338
SUMMARY
Lead economist with more than 15 years of global experience in universal health coverage, health financing, fiscal space, service delivery, and health systems including policy development and analysis, implementation support, and performance assessment working in several international organizations including the World Health Organization (WHO), Asian Development Bank (ADB), and the World Bank (WB). Led and contributed to high-level policy dialogue engagements, technical assistance, knowledge products, applied research activities, capacity building projects, corporate priorities, and strategic partnerships a
oss several countries, regions, and in collaboration with multiple development partners including IMF, WHO, Harvard University, Gates Foundation, OECD, GAVI, Global Fund, and DFAT, among others. Co-authored several books, peer-reviewed journal articles, and published reports.
EXPERIENCE
World Bank Washington, DC 
Jan 2010-Present
As program manager, lead the conceptualization, operationalization, and implementation of a multi-donor trust fund focused on supporting countries in integrating donor-financed health programs as they transition from external to domestic sources of health financing. Served on the expert team that developed the strategic priorities for health financing for GHNDR. Led and contributed to health financing assessments, public expenditure reviews, and health systems analyses for Indonesia, Lao PDR, Solomon Islands, Vietnam, Nepal, and Philippines. Co-authored Going Universal book based on compilation and curation of detailed health financing information underlying the expansion of universal health coverage programs a
oss 24 countries. Analyzed and led policy dialog on assessing the availability of benefits and of service delivery challenges in Indonesia and Lao PDR. Led supply-side readiness assessment for Indonesia government’s 2015-2019 five-year national development plan (RPJMN). Managed the implementation and impact evaluation of an innovative conditional cash transfer project in Lao PDR and contributed to the design of health financing and service delivery components for a primary care strengthening project in Indonesia. Led global analytical work on prioritization of health in government budgets, including dialoging with counterparts in ministries of finance and health. 
Jan 2007-Jan 2010
As member of health financing team with the then Health, Nutrition, and Population (HNP) central unit, led and co-authored the development and implementation of the WB’s fiscal space for health guidelines as well as an associated internal and external capacity-building program based on pilot case studies and policy engagements with teams in Uganda, Rwanda, India, and several other countries. Initiated and managed program of work related to institutionalization of National Health Accounts. Provided technical and operational 
oss-support to several task teams including for a public expenditure review for Ukraine. Contributed to the WB’s 2008 book on Good Practices in Health Financing based on experiences of Colombia, Chile, Costa Rika, Kyrgyz Republic, Estonia, and Sri Lanka, among other countries. Co-led and contributed to two-year review of the 2007 HNP strategy as well as the 2009 reproductive health strategy, both of which were presented to the WB Board.      
Jun 1996-Aug 1997, Summer 1994
As extended research intern in the WB’s Africa region, assessed the impact of adverse health on labor productivity of coffee plantation workers in Ethiopia. Analyzed household survey data for UNDP/World Bank/WHO Tropical Disease Research multi-country (including from sites in Sudan and Nigeria) research project on impact of parental health on children’s school attendance and on labor productivity. Researched inflationary impact of the January 1994 CFA franc devaluation in West African Monetary Union (WAMU) countries and revised economic assessment of a large-scale health sector project to incorporate changes in costs and benefits caused by the devaluation.
Ajay Tandon, page 2
Asian Development Bank Manila, Philippines
Aug 2004-Jan 2007
As an economist with the Economics and Research Department, researched and led policy dialog on issues relating to poverty, inequality, health, and education. Lead author for ADB’s 2006 annual flagship publication entitled Measuring Policy Effectiveness in Health and Education. Co-led implementation and analysis of investment climate survey and report for Lao PDR. Assessed inclusiveness of economic growth in China. Researched trends in income inequality in India. Reviewed methods for measuring ma
o-level efficiency of health systems. Co-led training workshops on impact evaluation methods.
Harvard University Cambridge, MA
Nov 2003-Jun 2004
As a senior research fellow with the Harvard Initiative for Global Health, developed and researched methods for mi
o-econometric analysis of health survey data. Developed and estimated index of health care need using self-report symptomatic items. Assessed “effective coverage” of health systems using 
oss-country household survey data.
World Health Organization Geneva, Switzerland
May 1999-Nov 2003
As an economist with the Evidence and Information for Policy Department, developed and implemented methodology for correcting bias in self-reported health data using anchoring vignettes. Developed methods for estimating household economic status using a series of asset indicator variables and mi
o-simulation models to assess determinants of demand for health. Contributed to the conceptualization and measurement of “effective coverage” as a way of assessing health system performance. Assessed performance and efficiency of health systems using frontier production function models and contributed to global, country, and sub-national capacity building and policy dialog engagements.
University of Oxford Oxford, UK 
Sep 1998-May 1999
As a post-doctoral research officer with the Centre for the Study of African Economies, taught Master’s level students econometrics and ma
oeconomics in Addis Ababa University, Ethiopia, under auspices of Oxford University’s Strengthening National Training and Research Capacity Program.
Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, VA
Aug 1992-Aug 1998
As research and teaching assistant with department of economics, cleaned, compiled, and analyzed the Social and Economic Characteristics of Households in Iran (SECHI) panel household survey data set. Analyzed four years of price data collected under the auspices of the United Nations International Comparison Program (ICP) for estimating purchasing-power parity exchange rates. Taught principles of ma
oeconomics to undergraduate students. 
EDUCATION
Virginia Tech Blacksburg, VA, PhD Economics, Aug 1998, Dissertation: “Essays on Development Economics: Issues in Ma
oeconomics and Population”, MA/MBA Political Science and International Business May 1992, Thesis: “Politics of Strategic Trade: South Korea and Mexico in a Comparative Perspective”. 
St. Stephen’s College Delhi, India, BSc (Honours) Physics, Jul 1987

	Date and Place of Birth		- 18, October 1966

	Address	            		- P.O. Box: 378, Jimma, Ethiopia

	Dean, College of Public Health and Medical Sciences, Jimma University

	Consultant Pediatric Cardiologist

column108:
Dr Ana Lucia Andrade is professor of Infectious Diseases Epidemiology at the Department of Community Health of the Institute of Tropical Pathology and Public Health, Federal University of Goias, Brazil. Dr Andrade obtained her Medical Degree from the School of Medical Science of Santos, São Paulo, Brazil, followed by a residency in Tropical Medicine at the Federal University of Goias where she earned her masters degree in Tropical Medicine. Dr Andrade completed her doctoral degree in Epidemiology and Public Health at the University of São Paulo, Brazil. She worked as advisor on Communicable Diseases Research at the Pan American Health Organization-WHO, in Washington, D.C. Dr Andrade has acted as Technical Consultant for Brazilian Ministry of Health/Immunization Program, and for the Pan American of Health Organization. She is currently member of the Tecnhical Advisory Committe in Immunization  for the Brazilian Immunization Program. In the last two decades she has coordinated several population-based studies in infectious diseases, granted by international and national agencies. She has published more than 100 peer-reviewed manuscripts, and book chapters. She is researcher for the National Council for Scientific and Technological Development in Brazil. Dr Andrade is member of national and international societies, and has served as an ad hoc reviewer for several international journals. Dr Andrades academic interests include the epidemiology of vaccine-preventable diseases and technologies for vaccine impact assessment.

Address to access this CV: 
http://lattes.cnpq.br/7770363683068899

column108:
I have over ten years of experiences in public institions and internatoinal NGOs in the area of public health and medicine. Currently, I am an epidemiologist at Oxford University working at KEMRI-Welcome Trust Programme in Kenya. My roles at OU include conducting and disseminating high quality research outputs in the area of child health and infectious diseases(malaria, TB, HIV and diarrehal diseases) and vaccines. I am also involved in coaching of PhD students in KEMRI and OU. 
My past expriences covered vast areas at Jimma Universtiy and International NGO. I have worked in Jimma University at different calibers. As an association professor, I have instructed epidemiology I and II, research methods and disease control and prevention for graduate programs. I have authored several teaching modules for MPH programs and the HEP of MOH. I have led several projects on TB/HIV and malarai as a PI. I have worked as Director of Publication and extension and coordinator of graduate programs. I have led the development of the research policy and the bussiness process re-engineering of Jimma University.  I have been involved in the management of Gilgel Gibe Field Research center. I have organized several national and internatoinal research conferences at JU. 
I have also worked as program Director of International Medical Corps in Sudan for three years. My roles included designing, implementing, moniroring and evaluation of all facets of the Primary health care proggrams in Darfur. I have expanded the program portfolio of IMC in Darfur by mobilizing more than 10 million Dollors annually from international donors (USAID, ECHO and UNDP). I have extablished TB/HIV program in Darfur and strengthend the health system through innovative approaches. 
Publications: I have authored more than 60 peer reviewed articles in International Journals. Most of them are available in the pubmed. Selected publications include: 
1.	Deribew A, Deribe K, Reda AA, Tesfaye M, Hailmichael Y, Maja T. Do mental disorders decline over time among TB/HIV patients who are on ART. BMC Psychiatry 2013, 13:174
2.	Deribew A, Deribe K, Reda AA, Tesfaye M, Hailmichael Y, Maja T, Colebunders R. Change in quality of life: a follow up study among patients with HIV infection with and without TB in Ethiopia. BMC Public Health. 2013 Apr 29;13(1):408
3.	Deribew A, Birhanu Z, Kebede D et al: The effect of training of household heads about the use of Treated Bed Nets on the burden of malaria and anemia in under-five children: a cluster randomized trial in Ethiopia. Malaria Journal 2012, 11
4.	Deribew A, Abebe G, Apers L, Abdissa AFetene Deribe, Woldemichael K, Jira C, Tesfaye M, Shiffa J, Asseffa A, Bezabih M, Abeje T, Colebunders R.  Prevalence of pulmonary TB and spoligotype pattern of Mycobacterium tuberculosis among TB suspects in a rural community in Southwest Ethiopia. BMC Infectious Diseases 2012, 12:54 
5.	Deribew A, Negussu N, Melaku Z, Deribe K: Investigation outcomes of tuberculosis suspects in the health centers of Addis Ababa. PLoS One 2011, 19;6(4):e18614

"Bedilu Girma
Lecturer and Clinical Anesthesia Specialist at Wolaita Sodo University 
Email: - anabedilu@gmail.com
Telephone: - +251913153776

Summary

I was born on the 12th of July 1983. I graduated from University of Gondar with a Bachelor of Anesthesia in
2009. I received a post-graduate Degree in clinical Anesthesiology from Addis Ababa University in 2014. I have served as the Head of Anesthesia Department at Wolaita Sodo University in 2011 as well as in 2014 and also as Academic Quality Assurance Coordinator as of July, 2015.
Currently I run Academic Quality Assurance and Enhancement Office in Wolaita Sodo University College of Health Science and Medicine. I am responsible for the quality of Education and clinical practices in the college. I am working with Higher Education Relevance and Quality Agency of Ethiopian and other local and international NGOs which gives me a great opportunity to update my knowledge. I won a grand community service project called “Mobile Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation Training for Health Professionals at Wolaita Zone” in Wolaita Sodo University which is based on my MSc thesis project. I have attended different local and international workshops and participated in curriculum development and design in Ethiopia Education system.
I am working in different committees in the university actively participating the university’s research and community service office.
Different Links
*Federal Ministry of Health – Ethiopia: I am one of the member of Item development tax force for licensure examination which is being delivered to all fresh graduates in Ethiopia.
*Federal Ministry of Education – Ethiopia: I was one of the active member of Curriculum Modularization process throughout the country.
*Higher Education Relevance and Quality Agency of Ethiopian: Works independently to enhance and assure the quality of education in the country and I’m one of the delegates of this organization at Wolaita Sodo University.
*Ethiopian Anesthetists Association: Worked as an Executive member of this association and works towards
*Safe delivery of anesthesia in the country.

column108: Abdur Razzaque Sarker a health economist researcher with particular expertise in conducting research in economic evaluation of various public health programs and economic consequences of various public health issues. Currently he is working as an assistant scientist of Health Economics and Financing Research Group of International Centre for Diarrheal Disease Research, Bangladesh (icddr,b) and post graduate researcher of University of Strathclyde, UK. He has proven experiences with healthcare financing, health insurance, equity in health, economics of vaccine and costing methodology.

column108: Organisation: Institute of Statistical, Social and Economic Research (ISSER), University of Ghana Name: DR. AMA POKUAA FENNY Profession: RESEARCH FELLOW Key Qualifications: Dr. Ama Pokuaa Fenny is a Research Fellow with the Institute of Statistical, Social and Economics Research (ISSER) at the University of Ghana. Since 2005, she has worked as a researcher focusing on developmental issues in health economics, health service delivery, social protection systems, regulatory governance and competition. She has experience in the area of health expenditure assessments having worked as a member of technical teams for UNAIDS in Ghana and in a number of African countries (Gambia, Eriteria, Mozambique, Liberia). Education: PhD. Health Economics, Department of Public Health, Aarhus University, Denmark 2014 MSc in Health, Population & Society, London School of Economics & Political Science 2004 BA Economics and Computer Science, University of Ghana, Ghana, 2000 Employment Record: 1. Sep 2015 – date: Research Fellow/ Health Economist, Institute of Statistical, Social and Economic Research, University of Ghana 2. Sep 2009 – 2014: Doctoral Fellow, Department of Public Health, Aarhus University 3. Sep 2005 – 2009: Principal Research Assistant, Institute of Statistical, Social and Economic Research, University of Ghana Working experience: International Dec 2013–Jan 2014: Access and Delivery Partnership project (PATH International), Tanzania. Project Research and Technical Assistance Sep 2013: Technical Assistance – UNAIDS Consultant, Liberia. Planning, preparation, training and writing of a comprehensive National AIDS Spending Assessment Report for the Republic of Liberia (2010/11 and 2011/12) Sep 2009: Technical Assistance – UNAIDS Consultant, Gambia. Coordination, training and writing of a comprehensive National AIDS Spending Assessment Report for the Gambia (2007 and 2008) In-country Jan – June, 2016: Member, Technical Team - Review of the Monitoring & Evaluation and Research Structure of the National Health Insurance Authority (NHIA) February 2016/ October 2015: Technical expert: PEPFAR sustainability index workshop to complete and analyze the Sustainability Index to accurately reflect Ghana’s progress towards a sustained response to the HIV epidemic. Sep 2007- 2012: Team Member and Coordinator National AIDS Spending Assessment (NASA), 2005 & 2006, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2010, 2011 Annual reports for Ghana, commissioned by Ghana AIDS Commission with support from UNAIDS, Ghana. July–Aug, 2010: Member of Technical Working Group Development of the Funding Mechanism Strategy sub section report to feed into the National Strategic Plan for HIV and AIDS (2011 – 2015), Ghana Review of Selected Research Projects 1. Cost of Healthcare Associated Infections (HCAI) and HCAI Control Interventions in Ghana - Post-doc Position/Fellowship on Ghana-HAI research project. Project Coordinator: Prof. Mercy Newman, Department of Medical Mi obiology, School of Biomedical and Allied Health Sciences, University of Ghana Aim: The aim of this study is to measure the direct, indirect and opportunity costs associated with HCAIs and HCAI control interventions in Ghana. These infections include Surgical site infections, neonatal and puerperal sepsis. Duration: (2016 - 2020) Funding Agency: Danish Research Council 2. Combining Vignettes and Item‐Response to Measure Process Quality in the Treatment of Malaria in Health Facilities in Kenya Aim: The aim of the project was to enhance the analytical capacity of health economist in sub-Saharan Africa using data from service delivery indicators project funded by the World Bank. Duration: (2015 - 2016) Funding Agency: AERC, Kenya Position: Researcher 3. Socio-Economic Costs of Violence against Women and Girls Aim: The study estimates the social and economic costs of VAWG by analyzing the direct and indirect costs (direct and indirect intangible costs) looking at the impact on the both the individual and society. Duration: (2015 - 2018) Funding Agency: DFID Position: Researcher 4. Undertaking of Public Expenditure and Implementation Review (PEIR) of the Health Sector Aim: The PIER is to provide a comprehensive analysis of public sector spending and outcomes and provide information on the public-private mix of goods and service provision, public expenditure priorities, the link between expenditure inputs and outcomes, and public sector institutional arrangements. This is an effort to streamlining spending and improving related outcome in the health sector. Duration: (2014 - 2015) Funding Agency: MOH Position: Researcher and Project Coordinator Publications (selected) 1. Fenny, A. P., Crentsil A.O., & Asuman D. (2017). Determinants and Distribution of Comprehensive HIV/AIDS Knowledge in Ghana. Global Journal of Health Science, 9(12). doi.org/10.5539/gjhs.v9n12p32 2. Fenny, A. P. (2017). Ghana’s Path to an Industrial–Led Growth: The Role of Decentralisation Policies. International Journal of Economics and Finance, 9(11). doi.org/10.5539/ijef.v9n11p22 3. Fenny, A.P., (2017). ‘Live to 70 Years and Over or Suffer in Silence: Understanding Health Insurance Status Among the Elderly Under the NHIS in Ghana’, Journal of Aging & Social Policy Vol. 29, Iss. 4, 352-370 DOI: 10.1080/08959420.2017.1328919 4. Fenny, A.P., Kusi, A, Arhinful, D.K & Asante, F.A. 2016, ‘Factors contributing to low uptake and renewal of health insurance: a qualitative study in Ghana’, Global Health Research and Policy, 2016, DOI: 10.1186/s41256-016-0018-3 F 5. Fenny, A.P., Asante, F.A., Arhinful, D.K., Kusi, A., Parmar, and Williams, G. 2016, ‘Who uses outpatient healthcare services under Ghana’s health protection scheme and why?’ BMC Health Services Research, 16: 174 DOI: 10.1186/s12913-016-1429-z 6. Fenny, AP, Asante, FA, Enemark, U & Hansen, KS 2015, ‘Malaria care seeking behavior of individuals in Ghana under the NHIS: Are we back to the use of informal care?’ BMC Public Health 2015, 15:370 7. Fenny, AP, Asante, FA, Enemark, U & Hansen, KS 2015, Treatment-seeking Behaviour and Social Health Insurance in Africa: The Case of Ghana under the National Health Insurance Scheme' Global Journal of Health Science, Vol 7 (1) 8. Fenny, AP, Hansen, KS, Asante, FA & Enemark, U 2014, 'Patient Satisfaction with Primary Health Care – A Comparison between the insured and non-insured under the National Health Insurance Policy in Ghana' Global Journal of Health Science, Vol 6(4)

I am teaching medical doctors and other professionals of health since the very early years of my graduation. In 1974 I was admitted as a teacher of anatomy and physiology at the Instituto de Ciencias Médicas in Maputo and the following year I was appointed has director of the same Institute. In 1977, working in another city of Mozambique. I was also the director of the local Institute for paramedical training. In 1981 I start teaching in the faculty of medicine of the Eduardo Mondlane University where I am still working now as associated professor of Medicine. From 1990 to 1992 I was appointed has the Dean of the Faculty of Medicine. Also since 1989 I have been involved in the training of future specialists of internal medicine, pediatrics, anesthesiology and intensive care. 
The second area of activity is research. My main area of interest is epidemiology of cardiovascular diseases and risk factors in Mozambique and its evolution throughout the time. I have done a national survey using the WHO STEPWISE methodology to evaluate the prevalence of risk factors for cardiovascular diseases in Mozambique in 2005 and I repeated it in the end of 2014. I am also involved with several other teams in Africa and also in Europe, United states and Canada.

I started my research work with the subject of my PhD thesis about hypertension, salt sensitivity and the renal dopaminergic system. It took me three years studding hypertensive patients and normotensive subjects and feeding them with a standard diet for a two weeks with the only difference of the salt content in each week and looking for the results in terms of 24 hours ambulatory BP and excretion of dopamine metabolites.  I have published a few papers:

a.	Acute hypotensive, natriuretic, and hormonal effects of nifedipine in salt-sensitive and salt-resistant black normotensive and hypertensive subjects. A Damasceno, Alejandro Santos, Manuel Pestana, et al. J Cardiov Pharmacol 1999; 34: (3): 346-353
b.	Deficiency of renal dopaminergic-dependent natriuretic response to acute sodium load in black salt-sensitive subjects in contrast to salt-resistants. A Damasceno, Alejandro Santos, Paula Serrão, et al. J Hypertens 1999 Dec;17(12 Pt 2):1995-2001.
c.	Influence of salt intake on the daytime-nighttime blood pressure variation in black normotensive and hypertensive subjects. A Damasceno, Paula Caupers, Alejandro Santos, et al. Rev Port Cardiol 2000; Mar;19(3):315-29
d.	Renal dopaminergic mechanisms in renal parenchymal diseases, hypertension, and heart failure. Soares-da-Silva P, Pestana M, Ferreira A, Damasceno A,et al. Clin Exp Hypertens 2000 Apr;22(3):251-68.

The second phase of my research was the result of a national survey with a representative sample of 3323 subjects with ages between 25 and 64 years looking for the prevalence of the major risk factors for cardiovascular diseases. The analysis of the data was done in collaboration with the Department of Public Health of the Oporto University. This result also in a  few publications.

a)	Hypertension prevalence, awareness, treatment, and control in Mozambique: urban/rural gap during epidemiological transition. Damasceno A, Azevedo A, Silva-Matos C et al. Hypertension. 2009 Jul;54(1):77-83. 
b)	Body mass index and waist circumference in Mozambique: urban/rural gap during epidemiological transition. Gomes A, Damasceno A, Azevedo A et al N. Obes Rev. 2010 Apr 7.
c)	Diabetes in Mozambique: Prevalence, management and healthcare challenges. Silva-Matos C, Gomes A, Azevedo A, Damasceno A et al. Diabetes Metab. 2011 Jun;37(3):237-44.
d)	Physical activity patterns in Mozambique: Urban/rural differences during epidemiological transition. Padrão P, Damasceno A, Silva-Matos C et al Prev Med. 2012 Aug 23.
Finally in the third phase the results of multiple collaborative studies with African partners and with the team from the Macmaster University come out.

a.	The Causes, Treatment, and Outcome of Acute Heart Failure in 1006 Africans From 9 Countries: Results of the Sub-Saharan Africa Survey of Heart Failure. Damasceno A, Mayosi BM, Sani M, Ogah OS, Mondo C, Ojji D, Dzudie A, Kouam CK, Suliman A, Schrueder N, Yonga G, Ba SA, Maru F, Alemayehu B, Edwards C, Davison BA, Cotter G, Sliwa K. Arch Intern Med. 2012 Sep 3:1-9. 
b.	Variations in Etiology and Management of Atrial Fibrillation in a Prospective Registry of 15,400 Emergency Department Patients in 46 Countries: The RE-LY AF Registry. Oldgren J, Healey JS, Ezekowitz M, Commerford P, Avezum A, Pais P, Zhu J, Jansky P, Sigamani A, Morillo CA, Liu L, Damasceno A, Grinvalds AJ, Nakamya J, Reilly PA, Keltai K, Van Gelder IC, Yusufali AH, Watanabe E, Wallentin L, Connolly SJ, Yusuf S; on behalf of the RE-LY Atrial Fibrillation Registry Investigators. Circulation. 2014 Jan 24. [Epub ahead of print]
c.	Prednisolone and Mycobacterium indicus pranii in Tuberculous Pericarditis. Mayosi BM, Ntsekhe M, Bosch J, Pandie S, Jung H, Gumedze F, Pogue J, Thabane L, Smieja M, Francis V, Joldersma L, Thomas KM, Thomas B, Awotedu AA, Magula NP, Naidoo DP, Damasceno A, Chitsa Banda A, Brown B, Manga P, Kirenga B, Mondo C, Mntla P, Tsitsi JM, Peters F, Essop MR, Russell JB, Hakim J, Matenga J, Barasa AF, Sani MU, Olunuga T, Ogah O, Ansa V, Aje A, Danbauchi S, Ojji D, Yusuf S; IMPI Trial Investigators. N Engl J Med. 2014 Sep 18;371(12):1121-30. Epub 2014 Sep 1.
d.	Characteristics, complications, and gaps in evidence-based interventions in rheumatic heart disease: the Global Rheumatic Heart Disease Registry (the REMEDY study).Zühlke L, Engel ME, Karthikeyan G, Rangarajan S, Mackie P, Cupido B, Mauff K, Islam S, Joachim A, Daniels R, Francis V, Ogendo S, Gitura B, Mondo C, Okello E, Lwabi P, Al-Kebsi MM, Hugo-Hamman C, Sheta SS, Haileamlak A, Daniel W, Goshu DY, Abdissa SG, Desta AG, Shasho BA, Begna DM, ElSayed A, Ibrahim AS, Musuku J, Bode-Thomas F, Okeahialam BN, Ige O, Sutton C, Misra R, Abul Fadl A, Kennedy N, Damasceno A, Sani M, Ogah OS, Olunuga T, Elhassan HH, Mocumbi AO, Adeoye AM, Mntla P, Ojji D, Mucumbitsi J, Teo K, Yusuf S, Mayosi BM.Eur Heart J. 2015 May 7;36(18):1115-22

column108: Abridged Curriculum Vitae ANVITA DIXIT, MSc My aim is to contribute to understanding and improving access to better reproductive health, leading to healthier lives for most vulnerable women and girls in developing nations. I want to play leadership role in public health providing direction to research agenda and contribute to generating strong evidence filling the gap between health research and well-planned interventions. My life, education and work in diverse international settings have enriched my awareness of global health issues preparing me for a research-centered profession. As a doctoral student I am working to expand my knowledge of psychological and social determinants of health and get advanced training in research design, robust methodological skills, which will equip me to take up more challenging research work independently.                                                                                                                                                                                               Current Position: Predoctoral Fellow University of California, San Diego Center on Gender Equity and Health 9500 Gilman Drive #0507 Division of Global Public Health La Jolla, CA 92093 Department of Medicine a2dixit@ucsd.edu                                                                                                                                                                                            Education: PhD, Public Health (Global Health), Currently pursuing University of California San Diego / San Diego State University Joint Doctoral Program in Public Health (Global Health track) MSc, Health Psychology, 2012 University of Sussex, UK BSc, Psychology with Sociology, 2010 University of Sussex, UK                                                                                                                                                                                            Employment 2016-present Predoctoral Fellow, Center on Gender Equity and Health, University of California, San Diego 2015-2016 Program Officer, Population Council, India 2013-2015 Assistant Program Officer, Population Council, India 2011-2013 Consultant, Population Council, India 2011 Intern, United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA), India 2009 UNICEF, Kenya 2009 Kivuli Center, Koinonia International, Kenya                                                                                                                                                                                               Peer-Reviewed Publications 1. column108: Since 1994, I have been at the University of Sao Paulo and my research has focused on cardiovascular diseases, contributing to the development of population and patient-based tools for the care of individuals affected by cardiovascular disease. Currently, my research focuses on the epidemiology and genetics of cardiovascular risk factors in the Brazilian population. I am pursuing translational research by collaborating with basic scientists, geneticists, statisticians, bioinformaticians, engineers, and health outcomes experts in several ongoing large-scale projects aiming at identifying and characterizing determinants of chronic disease in admixed populations. These efforts capitalize on well-established epidemiological and patient-based clinical studies that my group has developed in the last decade. I am currently the PI of the ongoing Baependi Heart Study, an ongoing, 10-years old, longitudinal, observational study being conducted at the Heart Institute, University of Sao Paulo Brazil to investigate predictors of cardiovascular disease in the population of Baependi, Brazil. EDUCATION/TRAINING: University of São Paulo MD 01/2000 Medicine Hospital das Clinicas, University of Sao Paulo Resident 01/2002 Internal Medicine Heart Institute, University of Sao Paulo Fellow 01/2004 Cardiology University of Sao Paulo PhD 01/2008 Genetics

column108: I am an internationally recognised leader in the areas of developmental stages of cardiovascular and respiratory health and intergenerational perspectives. An approach that situates the individual risk factors and their interaction within a context that determines health outcomes has been the underlying basis of my research. I am one of the Principal Investigator’s of the Mater-University Study of Pregnancy (MUSP) cohort. Over the past 12 years, I have been leading the cardiovascular and respiratory epidemiology research in the MUSP that included 30 years follow-up of the MUSP offspring cohort (Gen 2) and the first follow-up of the children-of-the-offspring cohort (Gen 3). In recent years, I have expanded my research in the low & middle income countries focusing on the rapid socio-economic development, environmental change and the demographic and epidemiological transitions. I have made significant contributions to understand the itical stages of life and early life determinants of cardiovascular and respiratory health. From the life course perspective, some of my papers are influential while thinking about the early development of health and well-being. For instance, my research confirmed that parents, especially mothers, are the role model for offspring health and well-being development from early life to adolescence and then to young adulthood. My research shows that weight management and prevention of obesity should start as early as possible even before or during pregnancy. I am interested to contribute new knowledge about the extent that socioeconomic, family and environmental factors track from generation to generation and how this impacts on health and well-being of the future generations.

NAME: Kandel, Amit	
POSITION TITLE: Clinical Assistant Professor of Neurology
University at Buffalo School of Medicine and Biomedical Sciences, SUNY, Buffalo, NY
	
EDUCATION/TRAINING (Begin with baccalaureate or other initial professional education, such as nursing, and include postdoctoral training.)
INSTITUTION          LOCATION	      DEGREE	      YEAR(s)	     FIELD OF STUDY

A. Personal Statement

The goal of my research has been to study and improve the stroke diagnosis, prevention and therapy. I have been involved as a resident, fellow and CO-PI in multiple researches in the field of stroke.  My interest includes stroke prevention, treatment in local and global settings. I plan to work in field of Stroke and general neurology in United States and Nepal.
