C. Selected Peer-reviewed Publications 

1.	Kandel A, Ching M, Farooq O, Gokhale R, Alfaro-Franco C, Li P: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a Patient with Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy. NAJMed Sci 2015; 8(2):100-104. DOI: 10.7156/najms. 2015.0802100
2.	Farooq O, Kirmani A, Agarwal N, Purushotham H, Kandel A: Visual diagnosis: 6-month-old boy with strange body movements. Pediatr Rev. 2014 Apr 35(4):e20-4
3.	Amit Kandel, Sirisa Kandel Amatya, E. Ann Yeh: Reversible diffusion weighted changes in Propioninic Acidemia, J Child Neurol. 2012 Apr 24. [Epub ahead of print]
4.	Amit Kandel, Marilou I Ching, Thomas J Covey, David W Shucard: Timing of Mobile cardiac outpatient telemetry may increase diagnostic yield of atrial fibrillation in select patients with cryptogenic strokes, Stroke, 2012; 43:A2437.
5.	Ghulam Mustafa, M. Waqas Masud, Sameer Gunukula, Maxim Mokin, Amit Kandel, Bijal K Mehta: CT perfusion deficits are present in acute transient ischemic attack patients utilizing 320 detector row whole brain CT perfusion studies and are associated with ABCD2 score, Stroke, 2012; 43; A3095.
6.	Mehta BK, Mustafa G, McMurtray A, Masud MW, Gunukula SK, Kamal H, Kandel A, Beltagy A, Li P: Whole brain CT perfusion deificits using 320-detector-row CT scanner in TIA patients are associated with ABCD2 score. Int J Neurosci. 2014 Jan;124(1):56-60


D. Research Support (non-industry/pharmaceutical support)

Ongoing Research Support 

NIH/NINDS                                        Johnston et.al (PI)                                     6/2012  10/2013; 2/2016  present
Platelet- Oriented Inhibition in New TIA and Minor Ischemic Stroke (POINT) Trial   
A transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a transient episode of neurological dysfunction caused by focal brain, spinal cord, or retinal ischemia, without acute infarction. An ischemic stroke is a cerebral infarction. In POINT, eligibility is limited to brain TIAs and to minor ischemic strokes (with an NIH Stroke Scale [NIHSS] score less than or equal to 3).
Role: Co-PI

NIH/NINDS/Univ. Virginia                    Hall et.al (PI)                                          2/2016  present
Stroke Hyperglycemia Insulin Network Effort (SHINE) Trial
The Stroke Hyperglycemia Insulin Network Effort Trial is a multicenter, randomized, controlled clinical trial of 1400 patients that will include approximately 60 enrolling sites. The study hypotheses are that treatment of hyperglycemic acute ischemic stroke patients with targeted glucose concentration (80mg/dL - 130 mg/dL) will be safe and result in improved 3 month outcome after stroke.
Role: Co-PI

NINDS/Univ. of Iowa/MGH.               Lyden et.al (PI)                                         2/2016  present
Safety Evaluation of 3K3A-APC in Ischemic Stroke (RHAPSODY)
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety, pharmacokinetics (PK) and preliminary efficacy of multiple ascending intravenous doses of 3K3A-APC, a Recombinant Variant of Human activated protein C (APC), in in the treatment of acute ischemic stroke following treatment with recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), mechanical thrombectomy or both.
Role: Co-PI

Genentech, Inch                                    Khatri (PI)                                              2/2016  present
A Study of the efficacy and safety of activase (Alteplase) in patients with mild strokes. (PRISMS)
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety, pharmacokinetics (PK) and preliminary efficacy of multiple ascending intravenous doses of 3K3A-APC, a Recombinant Variant of Human activated protein C (APC), in in the treatment of acute ischemic stroke following treatment with recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), mechanical thrombectomy or both.
Role: Co-PI

Bayer                                                      Hart (PI)                                                  2/2016  present
Rivaroxaban versus Aspirin in Secondary Prevention of Stroke and Prevention of Systemic Embolism in Patients with Recent Embolic Stroke of Undetermined Source (ESUS) (NAVIGATE ESUS)
This is a study in patients who recently had a brain attack (stroke) and in whom no clear cause of the stroke could be identified. These strokes are likely due to a blood clot and therefore, can be called embolic stroke of undetermined source. The abbreviation is ESUS. The study will compare 2 blood thinners. Patients will be randomly assigned to either Rivaroxaban 15 mg or Aspirin 100 mg and the study is intended to show, if patients given rivaroxaban have fewer blood clots in the brain (stroke) or in other blood vessels.
Role: Co-PI


                                   

Completed Research Support

NINDS/NIH/Univ. Miami                                        Ginsberg (PI)		 6/2012 - 10/2013
Albumin in Acute Stroke Trial (ALIAS)
The goal of the trial is to determine whether human albumin, administered within 5 hours of symptom onset, improves the 3-month outcome of subjects with acute ischemic stroke.
Role: Co PI


LUNDBECK A/S			                                                  	   6/2012  10/2013
Efficacy and Safety of Desmoteplase to treat Acute Ischemic Stroke (DIAS-3)
The purpose of the study is to determine whether desmoteplase is effective and safe in the treatment of patients with acute ischaemic stroke when given within 3-9 hours from onset of stroke symptoms.
Role: Co-PI

W.L. Gore and Associates                                        Kanser (PI)                      6/2012- 10/2013
GORE HELEX Septal Occluder for Patent Foramen Ovale (PFO) Closure in Stroke Patients - The Gore REDUCE Clinical Study (HLX 06-03)
The primary objective is to determine if patent foramen ovale (PFO) closure with the GORE® HELEX® Septal Occluder / GORE® Septal Occluder plus antiplatelet medical management is safe and effective and reduces the risk of recurrent stroke or imaging-confirmed transient ischemic attack (TIA) when compared to antiplatelet medical management alone in patients with a PFO and history of cryptogenic stroke or imaging-confirmed TIA.
Role: Co-PI

column108: DR. AJAY KUMAR KHERA F-5/5, DLF City I, Gurgaon Haryana-122002 India +91 9810206150 ajaykhera@gmail.com AREAS OF EXPERTISE • Recognized consensus builder of national and international stakeholders in advancing the maternal and child health agenda in India • Program management expertise including monitoring and evaluation of various public health program at National level namely integrated disease surveillance program, National AIDS Control Program, National Polio eradication Program, Reproductive and child health program, Universal Immunization program. • Specialist in epidemiological surveillance and outbreak investigation of communicable diseases including vaccine preventable diseases. • Extensive experience in immunization program strengthening • Expert trainer of basic and advanced epidemiologic surveillance and software • Technical expert in polio, HIV, TB, measles, leprosy and child health interventions including child nutrition. • Worked as International WHO consultant in Myanmar during the period 8th December 2014 to 7th March 2015 to provide technical assistance in roll out of Measles Rubella campaign WORK HISTORY DEPUTY COMMISSIONER AND PUBLIC HEALTH SPECIALIST, INCHARGE OF CHILD HEALTH 2010-PRESENT Ministry of Health & Family Welfare, Government of India, New Delhi • Plan, implement, and monitor child health related interventions at the National level by supervising a team of about 10 public health professionals with an annual program budget of about 500 million USD. • Coordinated the development of RMNCH+A Strategy for improved maternal and child health outcome with National and International experts under the direct guidance of Additional Secretary and Mission Director of Ministry of Health and Family Welfare. • Established laboratory-based surveillance for vaccine preventable diseases with special reference to introduction of Pentavalent vaccine in selected states of India. • Represented as technical expert in the development of guidance note for National Vaccine Policy with special reference to introduction of New vaccines under Universal immunization program. • Conduct periodic field visits to different parts of the country to review the implementation of Child health program. • Conduct quarterly review meetings with State program managers on various implementation issues related to child health and immunization • Conduct periodic child health and Immunization partner meeting with various stakeholders for reduction of child mortality • Lead the team of experts in investigation of adverse events following immunization so as to guide the state health authorities for suitable public health action. • Represent as Co-Chair and member on various technical committees constituted by the Government of India, namely National Technical Advisory Group on Immunization (NTAGI), India expert Advisory Group on Polio (IEAG), Technical Resource Group on Child Health (TRG-CH), Immunization Action Group (IAG), Neonatal Action Group (NAG) and Nutrition Action Group( NAG). ASSISTANT DIRECTOR GENERAL (TECHNICAL) 2004- 2010 National AIDS Control Organization, New Delhi • Technical program manager for National AIDS Control Program and supervised the team of program experts for strengthening the counseling and testing services and Sexually transmitted infection control component of the program. Also acted as focal person for strengthening HIV/AIDS surveillance in India. • Coordinated with agencies, including WHO, UNAIDS, UNICEF, UNFP, Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, and Clinton Foundation on various matters related to HIV/AIDS control program for harmonized action. • Periodic review meetings and field visits to various parts of the country to advise the state health authorities in program implementation. • Initiated Syndromic STI treatment kits for the first time in the country. JOINT DIRECTOR (EPIDEMIOLOGY) 2001-2004 National Institute for Communicable Diseases, New Delhi • Initiated the establishment of National Integrated Disease surveillance program for early detection of outbreak of communicable diseases • Involved in capacity building of state and district level program managers to understand the concept of surveillance and its use in regular program monitoring and evaluations. • Represented as a team leader in investigation of more than 20 epidemics of communicable diseases and mysterious diseases and suggested the state Government an evidence based public health action. • Established the WHO collaborating centre on Disaster Epidemiology and participated in 4 Rapid health assessment following disaster in different parts of the country. • Initiated training in GIS software and EPIINFO 2000. DIRECTOR 2000-2001 Regional Leprosy Training and Research Institute, Orissa • Trained various level of health workers in early detection and management of Leprosy under national Leprosy elimination program. • Carried out various operational studies related to program implementation. • Conducted periodic review with States on program implementation through discussion and field visits CHIEF AIRPORT HEALTH OFFICER 1999 Delhi Airport, New Delhi • Involved in implementation of International Health Regulations • Represented as a member of technical Committee for redrafting International Health Regulations • Led training of various cadre of staff regarding various protocols on International health regulations REGIONAL EPIDEMIOLOGIST 1996-1999 Ministry of Health, Sultanate of Oman • Strengthened the mother and child health immunization program, which is now recognized as one of the best in the region. • Monitored and evaluated Oman’s national health programs including the National Programme for Control of Blindness in the region. • Acted as Regional Coordinator of WHO’s National Survey on Causes of Blindness and Deafness. • Carried out Weekly surveillance of 20 notifiable communicable diseases including Trachoma using EPI Info software. • Conducted epidemiological investigations of 3 outbreaks of food poisoning and case investigation of sputum positive Tuberculosis cases in the region DEPUTY DIRECTOR 1991-1996 Division of Epidemiology, National Institute of Communicable Diseases, New Delhi • Provided technical support to various national health programs through development of program monitoring tools. • Coordinated with state health authorities on health matters particularly in establishing the communicable disease surveillance system. • Conducted 6 epidemic investigations on vaccine-preventable diseases across India. • Led field epidemiology training of district-level medical officers and trained more than 120 district level officers. • Represented Ministry of Health as a technical public health expert in various inter-ministerial teams during disaster situations. SENIOR MEDICAL OFFICER 198

column108:
Anteneh Asefa (PhD Candidate, Nossal Institute of Global Health, University of Melbourne)
  Assistant Professor, School of Public and Environemntal Health, Hawassa University
Level 4, Alan Gilbert Building, 161 Barry St, Carlton 
E-mail: antex98@yahoo.com, aasefa@student.unimelb.edu.au 
Skype address: antenehasefa
Phone: +61466806266
1) EDUCATIONAL BACKGROUND
Melbourne University, November 2016 to date
o PhD student at the Nossal Institute, School of Population and Global Health 
Addis Ababa University, September 2007 - April 2009
• MPH (Masters of Public Health)
o Study track: General MPH
o Research area: Assessment of quality of prevention of mother-to-child transmission of HIV services.
Hawassa University, College of Health Sciences Faculty of Public Health, September 2002 – April 2006
• Bachelor of science in Nursing 
University of Illinois, at Urbana Champaign, USA, June 2016 - August 2016
• Completed successfully the Public Management training for Young African Leaders Fellowship. 
Maternal Health Taskforce, Harvard School of Public Health, January 2013 - October 2013.
• Completed successfully nine months fellowship of Maternal Health Young Champions Program. 
Geneva Foundation for Medical Education and Research 
• Completed eight months training on: From Research to Practice, Training in Sexual and Reproductive Health Research, May-November 2011.
School of Public Health Addis Ababa University, EPHA and measure Evaluation
• Received regional training on M&E of Population, health and nutrition programs. Nov. 27-Dec. 06, 2012
2) INTERNATIONAL ACHIEVEMENTS  
• Received the Melbourne Research Scholarship, 2016-2020
• Received a full scholarship to Participate in the Mandela Washington Fellowship for Young African leaders, USA, 2016.
• Received a full scholarship to Participate and present a research paper on respectful maternity care during the Global Maternal and Newborn Health Conference held in Mexico City, Mexico, October 2015.
• Received a full scholarship to Participate and present a research paper on respectful maternity care during the Third Global Symposium on Health Systems Research held in Cape Town, South Africa, October 2014.
• Fellow of the Emerging Voices for Global Health 2014, Institute of Tropical Medicine, Belgium
• Presented my research work on respectful maternity in New Delhi, India, November 2013. 
• Presented a research on institutional delivery during the World Health Summit, 2013, which was held in Berlin, Germany. Featured as New Voices In Global Health. 
• Won the Harvard University’s Maternal Health Young Champions Fellowship, second cohort nine months scholarship award, 2013. 
• Attended the 2013’s Global Maternal Health Conference at Arusha, Tanzania.
• I have received a three days integral leadership training
• Received a full scholarship to Participate and present a research paper on PMTCT during the First Global Symposium on Health Systems Research held in Montreux, Switzerland, November 2010.
• Received a full scholarship to Participate and present a research paper on the 1st Pan-African Health Congress on Universal health coverage held in Ac
a, Ghana, November 2011. 
• Attended the international conference on population, reproductive health and economic development. September 2012.
3) WORK EXPERIENCE 
Health care management module coordinator, School of Public and Environmental Health, Hawassa University: September 2010 to January 2016. (Assistant Professor of public health)
Director of Public Health Services, Hawassa University Referral Hospital, Hawassa, Ethiopia: December 2010-June 2012.
HIV/AIDS mainstreaming focal person, College of Medicine and Health Sciences, Hawassa University, Hawassa, Ethiopia: September 2011 to date.
Assistant Lecturer, College of Health Science, Mada Walabu University, Bale Goba, Ethiopia: 
Dean, Enat Medical College, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia: August 2008 to May 2009.
Health care management module team leader, school of Public and Environmental Health, Hawassa University (September 2009 to October 2016)
Technical support to governmental and non-governmental organizations delivering preventive and curative health services (September 2008 to date) 
• Tasks: conducting in-service and pre-service trainings on health management information system (HMIS), ART, PMTCT, HIV Mainstreaming, gender and HIV/AIDS, district health planning and management.
• Reviewer of the BioMed Central open access publisher.
4) CONSULTANCY
• Independent evaluation of respectful family planning and abortion are services in “Michu” (comfortable) Clinic,  Federal Ministry of Health and Center for International Reproductive Health Training (CIRHT)
• Monitoring and evaluation of Maternal, newborn and Child Health Services, Family Guidance Association of Ethiopia and Comic Relief /Women and children First
• Integrated PMTCT/MNCH master trainer, Federal Ministry of Health
• Leadership, Management, and Governance in Health, master trainer, Federal Ministry of Health and Management Sciences in Health 
Other consultancies on 
• HIV/AIDS M&E (ART and pre-ART), HIV/AIDS mainstreaming, Health care financing, Integration of HIV/AIDS and RH services, HMIS scale up project, RH services Quality assessment, Community HIV/AIDS services evaluation, Woreda (district) based nutrition logistic services training, woreda (district) based health planning, district health management of MNCH services, EmONC, clinical mentorship assessment, PMTCT training and research, Health Systems research. 
5) PUBLISHED ARTICLES     
1. Asefa A, Bekele D. Status of respectful and non-abusive care during facility-based childbirth in a hospital and health centers in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. Reprod Health. 2015 Apr 16,12(1):33.
2. Gedefaw A, Tilahun B, Asefa A. Predictors of self-reported academic performance among undergraduate medical students of Hawassa University, Ethiopia. Adv Med Educ Pract. 2015 Apr 9,6:305-15. doi: 10.2147/AMEP.S78604. eCollection 2015.
3. Teshome W, Asefa A: Predictors of immunological failure of antiretroviral therapy among HIV infected patients in Ethiopia: a matched case-control study. PLoS ONE 9(12): e115125. doi 10.1371.
4. Deressa W, Seme A, Asefa A, Teshome G, Enqusellassie F: Utilization of PMTCT services and associated factors among pregnant women attending antenatal clinics in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, BMC Pregnancy and Childbirth 2014, 14(328) doi:10.1186/1471-2393-14-328
5. Asefa A, Teshome W. Total Delay in Treatment among Smear Positive Pulmonary Tuberculosis Patients in Five Primary Health Centers, Southern Ethiopia: A Cross Sectional Study. PloSONE, 2014. 9(7): doi10.1371.
6. Asefa A, Beyene H. Awareness and knowledge on timing of mother-to-child transmission of HIV among antenatal care attending women in Southern Ethiopia: a 
oss sectional study. Reproductive Health, 2013. 10(66).
7. Asefa A, Teshome W, Melese T, Letamo Y. Use of institutional delivery services in the Southern Nations, Nationalities, and People's Region, Ethiopia: a 
oss-sectional comparative mixed methods study. The Lancet, 2013. 382 (special issue).
8. Asefa A, Mitike G. Prevention of Mother-to-Child Transmission (PMTCT) of HIV services in Adama town, Ethiopia: clients’ satisfaction and challenges experienced by service providers. BMC Pregnancy and Childbirth, 2014 14:57.
9. Asefa A, Kassa A, Desalegn M. Patient satisfaction with outpatient health services in Hawassa University Teaching Hospital, Southern Ethiopia. Journal of Public Health and epidemiology, 2013. 6(2): 101-110. 
6) MANUSCRIPTS ON PROGRESS
1. Comparative analysis of methods and lessons learned from four prevalence studies on disrespect and abuse of women during facility-based childbirth
2. Evaluation of Respectful Maternity Care: questionnaires measuring women's experience in childbirth: systematic review 
3. Magnitude of intimate partner violence and its contributors in Chire district, Ethiopia

• Evaluation of PMTCT services in southern Ethiopia: WHO

8) COMPUTER SKILLS
MS word, Excel, Access, PowerPoint, EndNote, Epi info, SPSS, Epi 7, NVivo (beginner).

column108: Bilali Camara, MD, MPH- Medical Epidemiologist UNAIDS COUNTRY DIRECTOR FOR INDIA Background and Education I am a citizen of the Mali and the Netherlands, 59 years-old married with three children, a Medical Doctor with a Masters Degree in Public Health, a University Degree in Health in Developing Countries, and Certificates in: HIV/AIDS/STIs Clinical Sciences and Epidemiology, Tropical Epidemiology, Antimi obial Resistance and Medical Virology Laboratories from academic trainings in: • Mali: Ecole Nationale de Medecine et de Pharmacie, • Belgium: Tropical Institute of Antwerpen • France: Université de Nancy, Ecole de Sante Publique de Nancy • The Netherlands: o Erasmus University/ Dijkzigt Hospital, Rotterdam, o University of Leiden, Leiden o Tropical Institutes of Amsterdam (KIT) and Rotterdam (Havenziekenhuis), o the Municipal Health Services of Amsterdam, Rotterdam and Utrecht • Switzerland: Institut Tropical Suisse de Bale. Languages I speak English, French, Dutch, Spanish, Portuguese, Soninke, Bambara, and Fulfulde Experience Since May 2017, I am the UNAIDS Country Coordinator for India. From March 2013 to May 2017, I was the UNAIDS Country Director for Nigeria and UNAIDS Focal Point for the ECOWAS. Before this appointment, I served as the UNAIDS Country Coordinator for Angola from 2010 to February 2013. I joined UNAIDS in 2008 as the Senior Regional Monitoring and Evaluation Adviser for the Caribbean in the Regional Support Team. Before joining UNAIDS, I served from 1991 to 2007 as a WHO Epidemiologist for HIV/AIDS/TB/STI prevention and control in the Caribbean, Latin America, and North America. And before joining WHO, I have worked in 1990 as a research fellow at University Hospital Djikzigt in the Department of Dermatology and STDs in Rotterdam. From 1984 to 1987 I was a national Consultant for the Ministry of Health, UNICEF, UNFPA, WHO and Care-Mali in my native Mali focusing on the areas of malnutrition and starvation (malnutrition among children in Segou, and free food distribution and food for work projects in the regions of Gao, Segou, Timbuktu, Koulikoro and Mopti), and also conducted during the same period of time a comprehensive assessment of Sexual and Reproductive Health services in Kenieba, Bafoulabe and Kita (World Bank funded project). I have more than 30 years of international and national experience in health policy, epidemiology, clinical sciences, medical virology laboratories, advocacy and rights to health and resided or visited 50 countries in four continents for professional or academic reasons. I published seminal articles on HIV/AIDS/TB/STIs. I was a member of the United Nations’ MDGs working group representing the Caribbean region and until my departure for India I was a member of the Nigerian high level SDG working group, I am a member of the International AIDS Society’s Abstracts Review Board. Awards and Distinctions The World Health Organisation: WHO: Award for 10 Years of Service 2001, PAHO/WHO-Representative, Port-of-Spain, Trinidad and Tobago The Caribbean Community: CARICOM: Champion for Change Distinction. 2005, CARICOM Se etary General, HQ, Georgetown, Guyana The Caribbean Coalition of National AIDS Programme Coordinators: CCNAPC Lifetime Award for Outstanding Contribution, Dedication and Commitment to the Fight Against HIV/AIDS 2005, Chairperson CCNAPC, St Maarten, the Netherlands Antilles The United States- Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: CDC Distinction for an Outstanding Contribution and Dedication to Combating the HIV/AIDS Pandemic 2005, United States Ambassador on behalf of the US’ Government, Trinidad and Tobago The Caribbean Regional Network of People Living with HIV: CRN+ Special Award for Leadership and Achievement 2006, CRN+ Regional Coordinator at the 16th International Conference on AIDS, Toronto, Canada The World Health Organisation: column108:
Aletta E. Schutte is Professor of Physiology and funded by the Department of Science and Technology as the South African Research Chair in the Early Detection and Prevention of Cardiovascular Disease in South Africa  hosted by the Hypertension in Africa Research Team (HART) at the North-West University. She is also the Unit Director of the Medical Research Council Extramural Unit for Hypertension and Cardiovascular Disease. She is an Executive Council member of the International Society of Hypertension (ISH); the President of the Southern African Hypertension Society (SAHS); and one of 20 founding members of the South African Young Academy of Science (SAYAS).

She obtained her PhD in Cardiovascular Physiology in 2002 at the Potchefstroom University for CHE, and performed postdoctoral work in Australia in 2004. In 2008 she was the Founding Director of the Hypertension in Africa Research Team (HART). The research focus of HART is the identification of early markers for the development of hypertension, and ultimately the prevention of cardiovascular disease in the black South African population. 

She regularly receives invitations as speaker at international meetings (such as Australia, USA, Denmark, Germany and Italy) and has published over 130 papers on the topic of hypertension, cardiovascular disease and related conditions (View: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=schutte+a.e.). She supervised more than 50 honours, masters and doctoral students. 

She was acknowledged for her work as the winner of the Distinguished Young Women Scientist in the Life Sciences award, presented by the South African Department of Science and Technology; and the British Association Medal from the Southern Africa Association for the Advancement of Science (S2A3); she was the recipient of the Meiring Naude Medal from the Royal Society of South Africa, the AU-TWAS (African Union & The World Academy of Sciences) Award, and the NWU Institutional Award for International Leadership in Research. She was recently acknowledged by the Next Einstein Forum (NEF) in Africa  for a Fellowship Award as young leader in Africa (an AIMS initiative funded by the Robert Bosch Siftung).

Aletta serves on the Editorial Board of established cardiovascular journals, such as Journal of Human Hypertension, Current Hypertension Reports, Current Obesity Reports, serves on the Editorial Advisory Panel of Clinical Science, and is an Associate Editor of BMC Cardiovascular Disorders. She regularly reviews papers for journals such as Circulation, Lancet and Arteriosclerosis, Thrombosis and Vascular Biology. Aletta is the Principle Investigator of several clinical and population-based projects in South Africa, as evident from her publication list.

column108:
Andre Renzaho, (PhD, MPH, B. Nutr. & Diet.) is Professor of Humanitarian and Development Studies, School of Social Sciences and Psychology at the University of Western Sydney. Originally from the Democratic Republic of Congo, he has a background in Global Health, complex humanitarian emergencies, and Public health in low and middle income countries. His achievements have included overseeing  the evaluation of more than 40 AusAID NGO Cooperation Programs with World Vision Australia across the globe and as the Technical Director of the Impact Assessment of Australian Aid for the Bougainville Infrastructure;  occupying strategic positions with Care Australia, Concern Worldwide, Médecins Sans Frontières,  the United Nations High Commission for Refugees, and the United Nations Children's Fund; covering Sub-Saharan Africa, Eastern Europe, the Middle East, Latin America, the Pacific, and Asia. He has been a member of a number of governmental and non-governmental Boards, Committees, Expert Panels, and Taskforce.  

Professor Andre Renzaho has  published more than 160 papers and attracted more than $7 million competitive national research funding and consultancies. The majority of these outputs have been achieved in the last 5 years. Hi recent work in this area includes being the chief lead investigator for the study on Buruli ulcer in Ghana; mortality, nutrition, and food security study in Vanuatu, Mozambique, and Lesotho; the anthropological aspects of HIV/AIDS in Tanzania and Malawi; maternal and child health study in Laos; the evaluation of the emergency response in Kenya, Rwanda, Uganda and D.R. Congo; the evaluation of child sponsorship programs in Ecuador; the evaluation of AusAID support for child nutrition, and the evaluation of  the Urban Program on Livelihoods and Income Fortification and Socio-civic Transformation for the Youth in Kampala, Uganda.  

His experiences include oversight of global development and humanitarian programs; nutrition and epidemiological surveillance; communicable and non-communicable diseases in low and middle income countries, cultural competence in health care; policy development and analysis;  International health; human rights-based approaches to health and  planning; HIV/AIDS programming; program and financial management; contractual agreement negotiations; government and multilateral agency representation; and strategic planning and evaluation.

column108: CURRICULUM VITAE Anju Aggarwal, PhD Address: 1112 268th Way, SE, Sammamish, WA 98075 Tel:(301)-440-5159 Email: email2anju@gmail.com LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/anjuagg/ Citizenship: US Citizen SUMMARY • A public health professional with in-depth training and expertise in the realm of nutrition and health disparities a oss developed and developing countries. • At international front, I bring hands-on experience in planning, execution and management of maternal and child welfare programs in India both at the federal- and grass-root level, and coordinating efforts a oss non-profit organizations and the Government of India. • At domestic front, I bring 9+ years of experience in planning, implementing and managing multimillion dollar epidemiological research projects focusing on individual- and environmental-level determinants of poor diets and health. • 10+ years of experience fostering and managing multi-disciplinary and multi-institution collaborations. • 9+ years of expertise in designing research studies, research strategy, developing data collection tools and methodologies, and tools for data monitoring. • Expertise and 10+ years of experience in statistical data analyses of research studies, and premier nutrition and health surveillance datasets (STATA). • Excellent communication and organization skills, expertise in developing peer-reviewed publications for well renowned journals, and material for scientific conferences. • 9+ years of experience driving research teams and staff with proven results. • Experience in seeking and securing funding for meritorious federal grants. EDUCATION 2011 PhD, Nutrition track, Department of International Health Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health, Baltimore, MD 2003 MS, Nutrition, Graduated with Honors Delhi University, New Delhi, India 2002 Exchange Student Program – “Understanding Public Health Nutrition in the US” Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 2001 BS, Nutrition, Graduated with Honors Delhi University, New Delhi, India PROFESSIONAL EXPERIENCE Dec 2015 – present: University of Washington, Seattle, WA Titles: Acting Assistant Professor, Dept. of Epidemiology Project Director, Center for Public Health Nutrition Responsibilities: • Executing research studies: Serve as the project leader for federally-funded interdisciplinary research projects encompassing multiple disciplines: Nutrition, Epidemiology, Public Health, Urban planners and Geographers, Biostatistics and Medicine. I am charged with planning, development, coordination and execution of these research projects from start to the end. This includes development of research design and study protocols, formulating project strategy and work plans, fostering interdisciplinary collaborations, building and managing research staff team of 7-10, acting as a liaison between UW, NIH, Kaiser Permanante (Formerly Group Health) and Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center, and managing multimillion dollar project budgets. • Developing research proposals: Conduct epidemiological research on diet and health determinants. I am particularly interested in identifying the underlying drivers and barriers to healthy food choices and dietary intakes a oss socioeconomic and racial/ethnic groups. My past and current research pertains to: a) studying interactions among socioeconomic, psychosocial, and environmental drivers of food choices and their collective impact on diet quality and health, b) developing novel metrics to capture socioeconomic status or wealth, c) developing metrics and tools to study geographic distribution of behaviors, diets and health. Currently working on: a) expanding the ongoing research on food environment and psychosocial factors in the context of dual burden of malnutrition in low- and middle-income countries, b) cultivating the concept of nutrition resilience: how to eat better within socioeconomic constraints. • Teaching and mentoring: a) Serving as a Co-Instructor for graduate-level Nutrition courses, b) Actively serving as a guest speaker for undergraduate and graduate-level courses a oss departments, c) Actively mentoring students for Master’s thesis and manus ipt development. • Develop scientific reports and peer-reviewed publications: Lead the coordination and development of peer-reviewed publications and reports for the projects. Competent in conducting statistical data analyses, data interpretation and writing independently. 2016 – present: Govt. of Delhi and Non-profit Organizati

Professional profile
A passionate medical doctor with experience practicing medicine in rural and underserved areas. Always interested in research and applying best evidence in daily clinical practice. Also have direct field experience in providing clinical care to patients with tuberculosis and HIV and technical mentorship to clinicians and ART providers. Possesses excellent interpersonal, communication and team building skills, and capable of working independently or in a group. Enjoys multitasking and can work under pressure.
Objective
To learn evidence based health care and foster evidence based clinical practice in Nigeria and Africa by contributing to existing knowledge through publications and protocol development. To also build an extensive range of skills as well as theoretical knowledge in quantitative epidemiology and vaccinology.

BIOGRAPHICAL SKETCH


NAME: Ambroise Wonkam	
POSITION TITLE: Professor and Senior Specialist
eRA COMMONS USER NAME : AWONKAM	


EDUCATION/TRAINING  
INSTITUTION AND LOCATION	DEGREE	MM/YY	FIELD OF STUDY

University of Cape Town, South Africa  PhD; 2015; 	Human Genetics
University of Geneva, Switzerland	Specialist Diploma; 	2005; Medical Genetics, 
University of Geneva, Switzerland	D.MedSc.	2003	Cell Biology
Bar Harbor Courses, USA	Certificate	2003	Human Genetics
School of Genetic Medicine, Italy	Certificate	2002	Human Genetics
University of Yaounde, Cameroon	M.D.	1995	Medicine


A. Personal Statement. 
After a MD training from the Faculty of Medicine and Biomedical Sciences, University of Yaoundé 1 (Cameroon), Dr. Wonkam completed a thesis in Cell Biology in the Department of Morphology, University of Geneva (Switzerland). On a transgenic mice model, he evidenced that ectopic expression of Connexin32 leads to hypertrophy and hyperplasia of pancreatic insulin producing beta cells. He was awarded the 2003 Denber-Pinard prize for the best thesis from the Faculty of Medicine, University of Geneva. 
Other salient aspects of Dr. Wonkams background include his education as a medical geneticist at a highly reputable genetics department in Geneva. He subsequently practices medical genetics in both European and African contexts. Dr. Wonkams interests are reflected in more than 70 peer-reviewed publications, which are in laboratory, clinical, educations and ethical aspects of medical genetics. 
He was recently awarded for 2014, the very competitive UK Clinical Genetics International Fellowship from the British Society of Genetics Medicine.  Dr Wonkam is secretary of the African Society of Human Genetics, board member of Southern African Society of Human Genetics and the International Federation of Human Genetics Societies, member of the HUGO council.
Dr. Wonkam has a proven record on Hearing loss research among Africans. Specifically his research group has convincingly shown that Mutations in GJB2, GJB6 and GJA1 are not a major cause of non-syndromic deafness in Africans and should not be routinely investigated in clinical practice. Subsequently, he has investigated 10 Cameroonian families with autosomal recessive non syndromic hearing loss, using a massively parallel targeted sequencing platform: the OtoSCOPE® which incorporates 66 hearing loss genes. Causative mutations were identified in 7 families (77.8%): in MYO7A in two families and the following genes were involved in the rest: CDH23, LOXHD1, SLC26A4A, OTOF, and STRC. Twelve mutations were novel and secondary findings of variants of unknown significance were reported for 7 of the 9 families. Potentially exploring 3/10 of these families where mutations were not found, using Whole Exome sequencing could lead to new genes discovery. Jointly with Dr Leal, Dr Wonkam has the expertise and field experience to conduct the project proposed here to full success.

References
1.	Lebeko K, Bosch J, Noubiap JJ, Dandara C, Wonkam A. Genetics of hearing loss in Africans: use of next generation sequencing is the best way forward. Pan Afr Med J. 2015 Apr 17;20:383.
2.	Wonkam A, Bosch J, Noubiap JJ, Lebeko K, Makubalo N, Dandara C. No evidence for clinical utility in investigating the connexin genes GJB2, GJB6 and GJA1 in non-syndromic hearing loss in black Africans. S Afr Med J. 2015 Jan;105(1):23-6.
3.	Wonkam A, Noubiap JJ, Bosch J, Dandara C, Toure GB. Heterozygous p.Asp50Asn mutation in the GJB2 gene in two Cameroonian patients with keratitis-ichthyosis-deafness (KID) syndrome. BMC Med Genet. 2013 Aug 7;14:81
4.	Bosch J, Noubiap JJ, Dandara C, Makubalo N, Wright G, Entfellner JB, Tiffin N, Wonkam A. Sequencing of GJB2 in Cameroonians and Black South Africans and comparison to 1000 Genomes Project Data Support Need to Revise Strategy for Discovery of Nonsyndromic Deafness Genes in Africans. OMICS. 2014 Nov;18(11):705-10.

B. Positions and Honours

1995-1998: General practitioner, General medicine, Yaoundé General reference Hospital , Yaoundé (Cameroon).
1998-2001: Research fellow in Cell biology, Department of Morphology, Faculty of medicine, University of Geneva (Switzerland).
2001-2005: Medical intern (registrar) in Medical genetics, Service of Medical Genetics, Geneva University Hospital (HUG), Faculty of Medicine, University of Geneva, Switzerland.
2005-2006: Medical geneticist, consultant/lecturer, Service of Medical Genetics, Geneva University Hospital (HUG); Faculty of Medicine, University of Geneva, Switzerland.
2007-2009: Senior lecturer /consultant/ Head, Genetics and Developmental Biology & Service of Medical genetics Gyn&Obst , Faculty of Medicine and Biomedical Sciences- University of Yaoundé I  Cameroon &
Pediatric Hospital, Yaoundé  Cameroon
2009-2012: Senior lecturer / senior specialist, Division of Human Genetics, Faculty of Health Sciences
University of Cape Town, South Africa
2012 to 2015: Associate professor/senior consultant, Division of Human Genetics, Faculty of Health Sciences, University of Cape Town, South Africa
2015 to present: Professor/senior consultant, Division of Human Genetics, Faculty of Health Sciences, University of Cape Town, South Africa


Awards and Honours
	2002: European School of Genetic Medicine Award, Bologna, Italy
	2003 Denber-Pinard Prize for the best thesis, Faculty of Medicine, University of Geneva, Switzerland.
	2009: 3rd March of Dime International Conference on Birth Defect and Disability (ICBD) Award, New Delhi, India
	2010: International Data Sharing Conference, Oxford, UK 
	2011: ICHGS Award, October, Montreal, Canada
	2012 Geneva Heath Forum Award, Geneva, Switzerland
	2014 Clinical Genetics Society International Award, British Society of Genetic Medicine, UK
	2014 Human Genome Organization, future of Genetic Award

Current memberships
	Cameroonian Society of Human genetics, president
	Southern African Society of Human genetics,  Board member 
	African Society of Human Genetics, secretary 
	American Society of Human Genetics, Member
	European Society of Human  Genetics, member
	Swiss Society of Medical and Human Genetics, member
	International Federation of Human Genetics Societies, Board member
	Human Genome Organization, Council member 
	H3Africa consortium, steering committee member

C.	Contribution to Science

Genetic of hearing loss in Africa 
Dr. Wonkam has a proven record on Hearing loss research among African (1). Specifically His research group has convincingly shown that Mutations in GJB2, GJB6 and GJA1 are not a major cause of non-syndromic deafness in Africans and should not be routinely investigated in clinical practice (2-5). Subsequently, he has investigated 10 Cameroonian families with autosomal recessive non syndromic hearing loss, using a massively parallel targeted sequencing platform: the OtoSCOPE® which incorporates 66 hearing loss genes. Causative mutations were identified in 7 families (77.8%): in MYO7A in two families and the following genes were involved in the rest: CDH23, LOXHD1, SLC26A4A, OTOF, and STRC. Twelve mutations were novel and secondary findings of variants of unknown significance were reported for 7 of the 9 families (unpublished data). Whole Exome Sequencing of two of the 3 families that did not shown any mutation on the OtoSCOPE® panel has led to the discovery on a new gene of hearing loss (unpublished data).  The proof of concept that the use of WES in ARNHL among African families, could not only have major implication in practice for global African populations, but could lead to new genes discovery. 

a-	Wonkam A, Noubiap JJ, Djomou F, Fieggen K, Njock R, Toure GB. Aetiology of childhood hearing loss in Cameroon (sub-Saharan Africa). Eur J Med Genet. 2013 Jan;56(1):20-5.
b-	Bosch J, Noubiap JJ, Dandara C, Makubalo N, Wright G, Entfellner JB, Tiffin N, Wonkam A. Sequencing of GJB2 in Cameroonians and Black South Africans and comparison to 1000 Genomes Project Data Support Need to Revise Strategy for Discovery of Nonsyndromic Deafness Genes in Africans. OMICS. 2014 Nov;18(11):705-10. 
c-	Bosch J, Lebeko K, Nziale JJ, Dandara C, Makubalo N, Wonkam A. In search of genetic markers for nonsyndromic deafness in Africa: a study in Cameroonians and Black South Africans with the GJB6 and GJA1 candidate genes. OMICS. 2014 Jul;18(7):481-5. 
d-	Wonkam A. GJB2, GJB6 or GJA1 genes should not be investigated in routine in non-syndromic deafness in people of sub-Saharan African descent. Int J Pediatr Otorhinolaryngol. 2015 Apr;79(4):632-3.

Sickle cell Disease: genetic and public health intervention
Dr. Wonkam has a proven record on sickle disease research in Africa oriented in the used of genetics to address public health intervention. He has introduced the practice of prenatal genetic diagnosis of SCD in both Cameroon (1) and Cape Town. He has tractable record of studying psychosocial burden of SCD and genomic factors that affect the SCD phenotype, specifically HbF-promoting loci (2) and co-inheritance of SCD and alpha-thalassemia in Cameroon (3-4).  He is PI of an NIH funded  H3Africa grant aiming to examine ethical issues relating to sickle cell genomics research in Cameroon, Tanzania and Ghana (http://www.h3africa.org/consortium/projects). 

a-	Wonkam A, Ngongang Tekendo C, Zambo H, Morris MA. Initiation of prenatal genetic diagnosis of sickle cell anaemia in Cameroon (sub-Saharan Africa). Prenat Diagn. 2011 Dec;31(12):1210-2.
b-	Wonkam A, Ngo Bitoungui VJ, Vorster AA, Ramesar R, Cooper RS, Tayo B, Lettre G, Ngogang J. Association of variants at BCL11A and HBS1L-MYB with hemoglobin F and hospitalization rates among sickle cell patients in Cameroon. PLoS One. 2014 Mar 25;9(3):e92506.
c-	Rumaney MB, Ngo Bitoungui VJ, Vorster AA, Ramesar R, Kengne AP, Ngogang J, Wonkam A. The co-inheritance of alpha-thalassemia and sickle cell anemia is associated with better hematological indices and lower consultations rate in Cameroonian patients and could improve their survival. PLoS One. 2014 Jun 30;9(6):e100516. 
d-	Wonkam A, Rumaney MB, Ngo Bitoungui VJ, Vorster AA, Ramesar R, Ngogang J. Coinheritance of sickle cell anemia and ?-thalassemia delays disease onset and could improve survival in Cameroonian's patients (Sub-Saharan Africa). Am J Hematol. 2014 Jun;89(6):664-5

Capacity building and Genetic Education
Seminal work of Dr Wonkam have evidence the major need to increase genetic knowledge at all the levels of medical education in Africa  (1), through capacity building and the development of effective genetic services (2).  He subsequently invests in medical genetic research and report on an effective framework to increase capacity in human and medical genetics in Africa (3-4).

a-	Wonkam A, Njamnshi AK, Angwafo FF 3rd. Knowledge and attitudes concerning medical genetics amongst physicians and medical students in Cameroon (sub-Saharan Africa). Genet Med. 2006 Jun;8(6):331-8. 
b-	Wonkam A, Tekendo CN, Sama DJ, Zambo H, Dahoun S, Béna F, Morris MA. Initiation of a medical genetics service in sub-Saharan Africa: experience of prenatal diagnosis in Cameroon. Eur J Med Genet. 2011 Jul-Aug;54(4):e399-404. 
c-	Wonkam A, Mayosi BM. Genomic medicine in Africa: promise, problems and prospects. Genome Med. 2014 Feb 24;6(2):11. doi: 10.1186/gm528. 
d-	Wonkam A , as member of the H3Africa Consortium. Research capacity. Enabling the genomic revolution in Africa. Science. 2014 Jun 20;344(6190):1346-8. 

Medical / research ethics in genetics
Dr Wonkam have reported intensively on the majors challenges on ethics of medical abortion in genetic medicine practice in Africa: a call for policy action in sub-Saharan Africa to rethink diagnostics for pregnancy affected by  e.g. sickle cell disease: differential views of medical doctors, parents and adult patients predicted value conflicts (1-3). He subsequently extended his work of the others filed of research ethic including the challenges of the uses of genetics for gender testing in sport (4) that have great contributed to the policy of the International Federation.  Dr Wonkam through his work is also a strong advocate, in changing research ethics practice in Africa, that have offer failed to failed to follow the basic principles and the need to engage the communities . 

a.	Wonkam A, Hurst SA. Acceptance of abortion by doctors and medical students in Cameroon. Lancet. 2007 Jun 16;369(9578):1999.
b.	Wonkam A, de Vries J, Royal CD, Ramesar R, Angwafo FF 3rd. Would you terminate a pregnancy affected by sickle cell disease? Analysis of views of patients in Cameroon. J Med Ethics. 2014 Sep;40(9):615-20 
c.	Wonkam A, Fieggen K, Ramesar R. Beyond the Caster Semenya controversy: the case of the use of genetics for gender testing in sport. J Genet Couns. 2010 Dec;19(6):545-8. 
d.	Wonkam A, Kenfack MA, Muna WF, Ouwe-Missi-Oukem-Boyer O. Ethics of human genetic studies in sub-saharan Africa: the case of Cameroon through a bibliometric analysis. Dev World Bioeth. 2011 Dec;11(3):120-7.

ABHISHEK KUMAR
DOB: 14th January 1985


ACADEMIC QUALIFICATION

2015:   Doctorate in Philosophy (PhD) from International Institute for Population Sciences (IIPS), Mumbai, India.

RESEARCH/WORK EXPERIENCE

   2014:   Working as Monitoring & Evaluation Specialist in Uttar Pradesh Technical Support Unit (UP, TSU) under India Health Action Trust (IHAT), Lucknow Since 1st October, 2014. The project is collaborative effort of Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (BMGF) and University of Manitoba.

   2014:   Worked as Zonal Monitoring & Evaluation Specialist (Allahabad), for Uttar Pradesh Technical Support Unit (UP, TSU) under India Health Action Trust (IHAT), Lucknow during 19th February to 31st May 2014. The project is collaborative effort of Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (BMGF) and University of Manitoba.

   2009:    Worked as Research officer in project entitled Youth in India: Situation and Needs Study at International Institute for Population Sciences, Mumbai. The project was funded by Packard and MacArthur foundations. I worked in the project for six months, from 1st January  30th June 2009. I completed following tasks:

	Analyzed national level data.

column108: PROFILE I am an associate professor and National Heart Foundation Future Leader Fellow at Monash University and consultant physician at the Department of Diabetes and Vascular Medicine at Monash Health. I have a PhD in epidemiology, extensive training in clinical trials (NIH) and I am a Master of Public Health. I have expertise a oss the translational research continuum from human mechanistic studies to clinical trials and public health interventions through to practice. My vision is to establish new strategies for the prevention and management of chronic diseases, specifically obesity, diabetes and cardiovascular disease.  My goal is that my research findings translate into treatment guidelines, reduced diabetes and cardiovascular morbidity and mortality and reduced health-care costs. I am passionate about research of holistic approaches to prevent chronic diseases by promoting health. I believe this will impact not only the health of individuals but also be beneficial to our society and environment we live in. I have worked in a variety of international settings, as reflected by my appointments at prestigious institutions in the USA (NIH), Australia (Baker IDI, Monash University) and Europe (University of Copenhagen and Steno Diabetes Centre). I enjoy an active national and international research network. EDUCATION MD, MEDICINE AND SURGERY, Faculty of Medicine, Comenius University, Slovak Republic, 1998 (summa cum laudam) PhD, EPIDEMIOLOGY, Faculty of Medicine, Comenius University, Slovak Republic, 2002 (summa cum laudam) Specialty Degree, Internal Medicine, Slovak Medical University, Slovak Republic, 2003 Fellow of Royal College of Physicians, Royal College of Physicians, Australia, 2010 Master of Public Health, Monash University, Australia, 2012 SKILLS I have been fortunate to work in and learn from a range of different organisations, such as large governmental research institutes (the NIH in the US), private research institutions (Baker IDI, Melbourne), hospitals (The Alfred, Monash Health in Melbourne, Colonial War Memorial Hospital, Fiji, Derer University Hospital, Bratislava) and academia (Comenius University, University of Copenhagen, Monash University). This gave me exposure to and experience in very different management styles and fostered my leadership skills with small and larger teams a oss a number of cultures and technical fields. I have a broad knowledge of major issues and trends facing the health and public health systems in different countries. My specific technical knowledge covers the fields of clinical trials, pathophysiology, epidemiology and prevention of obesity, diabetes and cardiovascular diseases, health services and education. My experience in clinical research methods include clinical trials, systematic reviews & metaanalyses, statistics, methods: glucose clamps, intravenous glucose tolerance tests, muscle and adipose tissue biopsies and mi oneurography. EXPERIENCE Head of Chronic Disease prevention Stream, National heart foundation Future leader fellow, ASSOCIATE professor,  Monash Centre for Health, Research and Implementation, School of Public Health and Preventive Medicine, Monash University, Melbourne, Australia — 2014-present I lead the Chronic Disease Prevention Research Program at Monash Centre for Health Research and Implementation, School of Public Health and Preventive Medicine at Monash University. My focus is to establish new strategies for prevention and management of chronic diseases, specifically obesity, diabetes and cardiovascular disease through safe, low-cost and easily scalable interventions with potential to have an immediate public health impact to prevent and treat chronic diseases. My team consists of 4 PhD students (primary supervisor), 2 PhD students (secondary supervisor) and research assistant. I also assist with supervision and mentoring under PhD students at the department. Consultant physician, Department of Diabetes and Vascular Medicine, Monash Health, Melbourne, Australia — 2014-present I work as a consultant physician treating patients with diabetes at the Diabetes Support Service and Chronic Disease Management Clinics at the largest diabetes service in Victoria and Centre of Excellence in Management of Diabetes. Both clinics provide me with an opportunity to supervise junior medical staff including interns, residents, registrars and fellows. Visiting Senior Scientist, Steno diabetes centre, Copenhagen, Denmark — 2012-2013 Associate Professor, Faculty of Health Sciences, University of Copenhagen, Denmark, 2010-2013 Head of Clinical Endo inology and Metabolic studies, NHMRC Career Development Fellow, Baker IDI Heart and Diabetes Institute, Melbourne, Australia, 2004-2012 Advanced Trainee, Internal Medicine, Professorial General Medical Unit, Alfred hospital, Melbourne, Australia, 2009-2010 Adjunct Senior Lecturer, School of Public Health and Preventive Medicine, Monash University, Melbourne, Australia, 2005-2010 Visiting Physician, Dept. of General Medicine, Colonial War Memorial, Suva, Fiji 2003-2004 Research Fellow, US Fogarty Fellowship, National Institute of Diabetes, Digestive and Kidney Diseases, National Institutes of Health, Phoenix, Arizona, USA, 1999-2003 PhD student (part-time), Faculty of Medicine, Comenius University, Bratislava, Slovakia, 1998-2002 Thesis: Prevalence of insulin resistance syndrome, type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease in Gypsy and non-Gypsy population in Southern Slovakia. The research received Slovak Diabetes Association Research Award, Slovak Republic, 2004. Resident, Internal

column108:
Dr Alex Hakuzimana is a leading international expert in health policy and financing and a freelance consultant. 
He has 13 years of progressive experience in health policy and system research, in providing technical assistance and advisory services on health systems strengthening and health sector reforms to low and middle-income countries and management of interventional health programs. 
Since 2005, Dr. Alex has undertaken various consulting roles in the areas of program reviews, public health project design, implementation support and expert technical advice with several public and private organizations including the World Bank Group, the World Health Organization, GIZ, IntraHealth International Inc, Management Sciences for Health, Orasure Technologies, Internet.org, Clinton Health Access Initiative, EGPAF, HERA and Cordaid.
He has been a Subject Matter Expert in Results-Based Financing with Onfrontiers since 2016, a Healthcare Council Member with Gerson Lehrman Group, Inc. since 2015, a Senior Consulting Partner with BlueCloud Healthcare since 2015, a Business Advisor to a Rwanda-based women-owned firm, Alphat Company Ltd since  2015, and a lecturer in global health studies with the Euclid University since 2012. 
Over the last decade, he has been a part of the public health sector in Africa and holds expertise in health policy and financing, results-based financing, health systems analysis and health workforce, his current areas of interest include also healthcare market research and facilitation of investment in healthcare industry through private equity, health care marketing,comparative international health systems, international political economy, organizational and institutional economics, health technology assessment as well as international business and trade. 
Countries of experience include Rwanda, Lesotho, South Africa, Haiti, Belgium, Nigeria, Sierra Leone, Mozambique and Zimbabwe.
Dr Alex holds a medical degree from University of Rwanda, an MPH with specialization in health policy from the Institute of Tropical Medicine in Antwerp in Belgium and an MBA from Swiss Management Center University in Switzerland. 
He is currently undertaking a research project on fragmentation of health financing systems in East and Southern African regions for his PhD program at the University of Cape Town, South Africa.
He is currently taking a PhD course in Public Health at the University of Cape Town, South Africa.

Prof. Amany Refaat, MBBCh, MSc, MHPE, PhD
P.O. Box 350,  Fifth District, Cairo,  11835,Egypt
Tel: (H) +20-229299901	Cell: +20-122-3546245
E-mail: amanyrefaat@gmail.com ; amany.refaat@waldenu.edu
PROFESSIONAL PROFILE
University Professor with more than 30 years experience in  teaching, research , and conduction of international community-based public health promotion activities through: 
	Conduction of different applied and operational researches targeting women health problems on national and international levels with emphasis on Gender-Based Violence & Female Genital Cutting , Maternal & Child health and Reproductive health
	Long experience with management of large data sets( e.g. DHS) using  different statistical computer packages e.g. SPSS and proficiency in using different study designs and both of quantitative and qualitative data collection tools  Qualitative data collection approach include conduction and analysis of Focus groups discussion, and using different scales
	Online teaching and supervising research for graduate public health students
	Planning and teaching on line courses for undergraduate and graduate medical and health professionals students
	Planning , implementation and evaluation of community-based/competency-based medical educational programs and curriculum that aims to graduating competent physicians  responsive to their community health needs. 
	Planning and implementation of interventional programs among community members and health professionals targeting community health problems
EDUCATION

	Ph.D.: Public Health, Faculty of Medicine, Suez Canal University, Egypt, Oct. 1993 (Equivalency to Ph.D. in public health from regionally accredited institutions in the United States, Oct. 1996).

Research skills and competences
Computer skills and data analysis
1. Database handling, planning and design of study (large health care databases, real-world primary data, health/hospital registry, ICD, READ and ATC codes, survey, health outcomes )
2. Informatics and software packages (SAS, Stata, R, Linux/Unix, SPSS, PASS, GraphPad)
3. Data visualization (Tableau, Qlik)
4. Systematic literature reviews to identify, evaluate and synthesize evidence from relevant epidemiological studies(2010-present)
5. High-performance computing (Affiliated with Lisa Cluster Computer)
6. Genetic data analysis and bioinformatics (PLINK, Allgero (Linkage analysis), Merlin (Pedigree analysis), GenABEL (GWAS analysis for quantitative, binary and time-tsill-event traits), BLAST, Bioconductor (high-throughput genomic data analysis), WGAViewer, Haploview, METAL
 
Written communication skills, reports
7. Scientific Publications in peer-reviewed/international journals
2005-2016: 57 papers published/in press
8. Abstracts and presentations
2007-2016: 27 oral/poster presentations
9. Professional Service
Organizations: 50th EASD Annual Meeting, invited as a Poster Chairperson
Critical appraisal -Journals: Annals of Internal Medicine, Circulation, Archive of internal Medicine, Annals of Medicine, Diabetes, Diabetologia, Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism, American Journal of Epidemiology, European Journal of Epidemiology, BMC Medicine, PLoS Medicine, PLoS Genetics, PLoS ONE, Journal of Clinical Epidemiology, Scientific Reports, European Journal of Clinical Investigation, BMJ open, International Journal of Dermatology, Digestive Diseases and Sciences, Diabetes Research and Clinical Practice, Thyroid, Atherosclerosis, JAHA
Critical appraisal -Grants: Research Councils UK, Diabetes UK, Wellcome Trust/DBT India Alliance
 
Management and transferable skills
1. Plan and conduct a research project supported by the Rubicon grant (Affiliated with UMCG and University of Cambridge) (2013-2015)
Title of project: Identification of relevant biomarkers for the etiology of type 2 diabetes using new genetic concepts
2. Lead a systematic approach to study biomarkers, collaborating with an EU Innovative Medicines Initiative (IMI) Metabolic consortium (2013-present)
3. Networking and lead projects?
Collaborating between departments of epidemiology (UMCG) MRC Epidemiology Unit (University of Cambridge) (2013-present)
Flexible working in with multidisciplinary teams at departments of epidemiology and internal medicine, UMCG (2009-2013), engaged in international working groups (the KORA S4/F4, Germany; Julius center, UMCU, the Netherlands)
 
4. Stick to timelines and milestones and finalize project deliverables (Nominee for the best scientist report PREDICCt project)
5. Manage multiple tasks, working with multiple directors and team-leaders for varying projects  
6. Initiate new collaboration and implement/integrate epidemiological databases (the Mondriaan project, a Dutch population-based registry of pharmacy and hospital records)
7. Conduct advanced statistical analysis, design epidemiological study, clinical trials and write grant proposals (including survival analysis, longitudinal data analysis, multivariate regression, propensity score matching, sensitivity analysis, instrumental variable analysis, Mendelian randomization)
8. Instructing and training, people management
Epidemiology/biostatistics consultant for scientist and clinical researcher, international students (International Student Congress of Medical Sciences Research fellowship, 2010), visiting PhD fellows (2010), MD/PhD fellows (2012-2013) and other PhD and research fellows (2011-present), international Bachelor students (2010-2011)
9. Develop project plans and standard operating procedures (SOPs) for observational studies
10. Provide support and research advise for diverse academic and research groups conducting applied health or social care research

column108: AE isa practicing neurologist (Hôpital Universitaire de La Pitié Salpêtrière) and research professor in epidemiology. The main focus of his research is ageing of the central nervous system, through (1) studies on risk factors and consequences of decline in moor function and disability in older adults, and (2) research on risk factors (environmental, genetic susceptibility) and prognosis of Parkinson’s disease and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.
column152: Hôpital Paul Brousse, Bâtiment 15/16, 16 avenue Paul Vaillant Couturier

column108: QUALIFICATIONS M.B., B.S. (1974): Bangalore Medical College, Bangalore, M.D. (Pathology) 1978-81 Bangalore Medical College, Bangalore University, with Dissertation on 'Malignant Lymphoma-Imprint smear and Haematological Study'. M.P.H. –Master of Public Health (Epidemiology) 1987-89 School of Public Health and Community Medicine, University of Washington, Seattle, USA, with . a) Thesis on ‘Myeloid Leukemia as Second Primary: a case control study’ (paper published). b) Epidemiology of Adult T-cell leukemia-lymphoma (paper submitted for cancer epidemiology course) c) Environmental factors in the Etiology of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (paper submitted for environmental epidemiology course) d) Incidence and Survival Patterns of Kidney Cancer in the United States by Histological Type (study done for research assistantship). Fellowship of International Union Against Cancer - ICRETT (six weeks) 1984. Fellowship of the International Agency for Research on Cancer (WHO) (one year) 1984-85 - cited as an example of success among 446 IARC fellows from 1966-96 in the IARC brochure (April 1997). column108: Date: April, 2017 Applying for GBD collaborator Dear sir/ madam, As your Institute announced, I would like to apply for the post of Global burden of disease collaborator I was graduated by BSc in Public Health in 2010/11 GC. Then after one year I joined Addis Ababa University and studied Masters of Public Health in Epidemiology. In addition, I have more three years of work experience in the area of teaching at Madda Walabu University. At this moment, I am teaching courses like Epidemiology and Biostatics at Madda Walabu University at the rank of lecturer. So that if I will get the chance to join this position as a GBD collaborator my educational level and experience provides me to perform the duties attached to it well. I am very much ready to contribute my best experience in a manner that can serve as an input to in ease the performance of the activity to be carried out. For the detail, you can see from my Curriculum Vitae attached to this paper I will be available at: phone No: +251938048748 Thank you for your consideration in advance. Sincerely yours Bikila Lencha (BSc Public Health, MPH Epidemiologist, Lecturer) CURRICULUM VITAE Name: Bikila Lencha (BSc, MPH-Epidemiology) Personal information Name: Bikila Lencha Gemechu Sex: Male Birth place: Oromia Region, West Wollega, Ghimbi Town Date of birth: May 26, 1989 Nationality: Ethiopian Marital status: Single Contact Address: Bale-Goba, P.O.Box. 302, Cell phone: +251- 938048748/e-mail: lenibikimule@gmail.com/ bikilalencha@ymail.com A. Educational background Level Institution Year (GC) Qualification Higher education Addis Ababa University 2012-2014 MPH-Epidemiology(certified) Wollega University 2007-2010 B.Sc. Public Health(certified) Secondary school GCHS(Ghimbi) 2003-2006 Certificate Primary school Malka bidiru (Ghimbi) 1995-2002 Certificate , B. Work experience Date of work Place of work Position occupied Nature of work 2011-2012 Mada Walabu university Instructor, graduate assistant, supervisor Fulltime 2014-present Mada Walabu university Lecturer, researcher, Advisor Fulltime C. Professional expertise and skills I have been teaching in Madawalabu University since January 2011. While my stay in Madawalabu University I was teaching courses like epidemiology, Biostatistics, Communicable diseases control, Health Ethics and Legal medicine, physiology. I have also experience of teaching accelerated medical students the module which is called measurement in health and disease that includes both Epidemiology and Biostatistics. In addition, I have been teaching Master of Public Health (RH and GMPH) students since September 2015. Beside this, I have been supervising graduate health officer students during their field works like: community health practice and Team Training Program at different sites in Bale Zone. I am serving as an advisor for student research projects. In addition, I have been conducting researches on different health related problems. Training HDP (Higher Diploma Program) from Madda Walabu University-Certified Training of SAS softwere from Madawalabu University (Certified) Training on exam development –certified RHCS (Reproductive Health Commodity Security training) from Addis Ababa University-uncertified SBMR-Standard Based Management and Recognition from Madawalabu University-uncertified Harmonized Curriculum Review of Public Health and other Health science students- uncertified Business Process Reengineering (BPR) Publications 1) Insecticide Treated Net Utilization among Under-Five Children and its barriers in Adami Tulu District, Oromia Regional State, Ethiopia: A Qualitative study -PI 2) Knowledge and Attitude towards blood donation and associated factors among Madda Walabu University Students, Southeast Ethiopia - CO 3) Adherence to Antiretroviral Therapy and Associated Factors among People Living with HIV/AIDS at Goba Hospital, Southeast Ethiopia: An Institutional based study –PI Online to be published soon 1. Computer skills like Excel, Internet applications and others. Good skill of software like SPSS, Epi info, Epi data, STATA and SAS H. Legalities - I have never been convinced any ime. I. +91-9395113419 • Phone: +91 40-27019141 • Fax: +91-40-27019141 • Email: avulalaxman@yahoo.com ________________________________________ Senior level assignments in Medicine and Public Health/ Maternity and Child Care ________________________________________ EXECUTIVE SUMMARY • Versatile and seasoned community Medicine and Public health professional with a strong academic background and multi-functional experience with inter sectoral collaboration with Government, bilateral and multilateral agencies. • Currently associated with National Institute of Nutrition (NIN) and National Nutrition Monitoring Bureau (NNMB) as Scientist F (Senior Deputy Director) and Head, Division of community studies, NIN, Hyderabad. • Successfully completed several national, state, sub-state level epidemiological, operational, RCT trials in ‘Public Health Nutrition’ and involved in many trainings & capacity building programmes pertaining to public health and nutrition. • An expert Committee member in several National and State level committees pertaining to health and nutrition departments such as Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR), Department of Science and Technology (DST), Ministry of Human Resource Development (HRD)-Mid Day Meal, DWCD-Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) Scheme, National Disaster Management Authority, Ministry of Defense, Food Safety and Standard Authority of India (FSSAI), INCLEN-Trust International. • Great ability to work in team spirit with proven track record to consistently raise efficiency levels of government functionaries (200 staff), civil societies, community, promoting livelihoods of poor and marginalized sections. • A decisive leader with excellent ability to coordinate with different people at one time under difficult situations and the ability to bring out the best in others while eating a healthy & friendly work environment, thus enhancing operational efficiency. • Excellent man-management, time management and leadership skills. Core Competencies: • Research & Development • Medical Advisory Services • Management • Examination Skills • Patient Relations • Public Dealing Skills • Budgetary Control • Problem Solving • Resource Planning • Administration • Team Management ________________________________________ CAREER CONTOUR Growth-path…………. Scientist F (Senior Deputy Director) : Sep’11- till date Scientist E (Deputy Director) : May’06 – Aug’11 Scientist D (Assistant Director : May’01 - May’06 Scientist C (Senior Research Officer) : May’96 – May’01 Scientist B (Research Officer) : Nov’93 – May’96 Scientist A (Assistant Research Officer) : Apr’92 – Nov’93 Key Deliverables: • Designing and negotiating research protocols in the area of Public Health Nutrition. • Re uiting, training, standardization of investigators on various methodologies adopted in various health and nutrition surveys. • Execution of epidemiological, operational and RCT at National, State, Sub-state and district levels research studies. • Writing of the reports and recommendations and submitting to the planning commission and other relevant government and non-governmental authorities. • Formulating various strategies and policies for prevention and control of undernutrition and non-communicable diseases (Double burden of diseases) for the use at State and central level. • Fixing of food rations and managing of complex emergencies such as drought, floods, Tsunami etc. • Participating with national authorities, non-government organizations and international organizations to formulate the Maternal, Newborn and Reproductive Health and Research Regional and country health programmes and to develop plans and activities to implement these programme activities. • Identifying the priorities and action plans for meeting the medical objectives. • Administering the support to community medical services and providing advice, guidance and supervision of and to consultants and colleagues. • Facilitating and coordinating with donors to mobilize extra-budgetary resources to meet the programme needs. • Identifying training needs and organizing Regional educational activities. • S utinizing research proposals for bidding for funds, advising on relevance and technical aspects of their design. • Interpreting the organization's policies with respect to difficult and complex cases. • Performing any other related functions as required and may be assigned from time to time. Highlights: • Proficiently reviewed several scientific papers of European Journal of clinical Nutrition, Food & Nutrition Bulletin, Asia pacific journal of clinical Nutrition, Indian Pediatrics and Indian Journal of Medical Research. • Actively participated in several conferences/seminars/workshops as invited guest speaker. • Expert group member in the National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA), Government of India. • Life member in Indian Public Health Association (IPHA) and Nutrition society of India (NSI) and member in Indian Dietetic Association. • Completed Several Epidemiological, Operational Research projects and Randomized control Trials (RCTs). • Worked as the Faculty Member since 2001, for the following regular and ad hoc training programs are being conducted in the Institute for M. Sc Applied Nutrition, post graduate certificate in Applied Nutrition, Anemia and endo inology training programmes and many Ad hoc training programmes being organized time to time at institute. • Institute administrative responsibilities are also being carried out in running of welfare clinic for the employees and their dependants/ èche for the children of employees/vice-president for NIN-Employees Cooperative Credit Society. column108:
Alberto Freitas is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Community Medicine, Information and Health Decision Sciences (MEDCIDS), at Faculty of Medicine of University of Porto. In 2007 he achieved the PhD at the School of Economics and Management of the University of Porto with a thesis on the use of data mining techniques for the analysis of hospital inpatient databases. He is member of the Health Informatics group of CINTESIS (cintesis.eu) and has been involved in projects in several areas of health information systems, including data quality, data analysis, data mining, performance and quality indicators, coding and audit. He has lectured several disciplines on Biostatistics, Hospital Management, and Medical Informatics of pre and post-graduation courses (http://orcid.org/0000-0003-2113-9653).

Profile Statement 
I have a tangible and practical understanding of public health in resource limited setting and its global perspective in general. My competencies include diverse perspectives of primary health care, project implementation, clinical medicine, training of lower level health workers and managing HIV/AIDS programs with 6 years of field experience in Ethiopia, South Sudan and Uganda. During  my academic and professional accomplishments demonstrated tremendous  strengths in critical problem solving, analysis, and project leadership. Striving to be a public health researcher in global health, epidemiology, environmental health, infectious disease, health economics and/or health systems in global hemisphere.

International Medical Corps South Sudan 		November  2010  December 2011
?	On assignment I have conducted a baseline assessment of the HIV/AIDS programs at Tambura County in South Sudan.

?	Through a continuous supportive supervision and mentorship I assisted the health staffs to improve their utilization of GoSS MoH HMIS tools like Client follow up card, ART register, pre ART register, TB screening sheet and monthly reporting formats as a result the data source and data quality had improved. Efficient utilization of the TB screening sheet helps HIV positive clients assessed for TB at each visit both at the pre ART and ART clinic
?	Developed and prepared three project concept papers and participated in project design and development of the different IMC projects in South Sudan 

Management Science for Health (MSH  Ethiopia) 		January   October 2010 
Achievements
?	As an Integration advisor I have coordinated the provision of comprehensive HIV/AIDS service at 64 ART health centers and 61 Pre ART health centers. Thus played momentous role in which case more than 66,459 pregnant mothers have access to HIV testing (with 0.8% HIV prevalence of newly tested), 635 HIV positive mothers provided with PMTCT. As well more than 5310 HIV patients started with antiretroviral therapy.
?	Conducted an operational research on standard of care. Assessment of the different HIV/AIDS programs in view of evaluating the quality of care provided. Under this operational assessment 64 ART health centers and additional 61 pre ART health centers were evaluated in the standard of care in view of PMTCT, ART, TB/HIV and Pediatrics ART. Personal Information:
Arian Hatefi
533 Parnassus Avenue, Box 0131 
San Francisco, CA 94143 USA

E-mail: arian.hatefi@ucsf.edu
Personal Narrative: I am an academic physician and global health policy researcher at University of California San Francisco.  As a physician I have an intimate understanding of the determinants of health, health care service delivery, and health system organization.  Through my work and training, I have gained a sound understanding of health economics, priority setting, epidemiology, and translating evidence into policy.  I am fundamentally interested in global health stewardship to promote and improve health for all people worldwide.
Experience:
2014-present Assistant Clinical Professor
 Division of Hospital Medicine, Department of Medicine
 Global Health Sciences Affiliated Faculty
 University of California San Francisco
2015-2016 Global Strategy to Improve Mixed Health System Stewardship
 University of California San Francisco
A Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation grant to develop a shared strategy for BMGF, USAID, DfID, and the World Bank Group to promote effective health system stewardship worldwide
2015-2016 Co-founder, Global Hospitals Consultancy—Division of Hospital Medicine
 University of California San Francisco
I helped form an initiative to support hospitals worldwide.  I focused on ma
o issues of integrating hospital and acute care into the global health system strengthening strategy
 
2014-2015 Policy and Finance Analyst—Malaria Elimination Initiative, Global Health Group

Led a systematic review on economic evaluations of national malaria elimination programs and developed a national investment case framework for malaria elimination
