column108: Alessandra Lafranconi Mobile: 0039 347 48 65 077 Email: lafranconi.ale@gmail.com Skype: alessandra.lafranconi I have been working in public health for over 5 years: Visiting Scientist at EC Joint Research Centre and Jean Monnet Module Coordinator at University Milano Bicocca are two among my most recent jobs. My research interests are nutrition, food systems and environmental health. Leader by nature and coach by nurture, I aim to enhance public health in the European Region. EDUCATION Università degli Studi Milano Bicocca, School of Hygiene & Preventive Medicine (Public Health) Milan (IT) Medical specialist, Magna cum Laude, recipient of numerous funding (EUPHA, YFG, ASEM, ASPHER, CMCC-ICCG, YiA) 2012-17 Cyprus International Institute in association with Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health Limassol (CY) M.Sc. Environmental Health, Valedictorian 2010-11 Università degli Studi Milano Bicocca, School of Medicine Milan (IT) M.D., Magna cum Laude, External Training: Poznan University of Medical Sciences (18 months), Hospital Universitario Marqués de Valdecilla (1 month), Harvard TH Chan School of Public Health (3 months), World Health Organization HQ (2 months) 2004-10 MOST RELEVANT WORK EXPERIENCE Università degli Studi Milano Bicocca: Jean Monnet Module Coordinator “Development for health” Milan (IT) Areas of teaching and work: sustainable development, public health, non-formal learning 2016-current Public Health Consultant Milan (IT) Diet-related chronic diseases (JPI HDHL, European Commission, 2017-current), Consumers and society (BEUC-Altroconsumo, 2017-current), Food safety and global burden of disease (FERG group, World Health Organizaton, 2013-14), Water supply and terrorism (“Upsidedown Protect”, Lombardy Region, 2013-14) 2013-14, 2017-current Local Sanitary Agency (ASL): Community Public Health Practitioner and Family Doctor Lecco, Milan (IT) Areas of work: workplace health promotion, drug appropriateness, production planning & control, territorial care 2012-current European Commission, Joint Research Centre (JRC), Health in Society: Visiting Scientist Ispra (IT) Areas of work: nutrition and physical activity, health inequalities, health policy 2016-17 A.O. Papa Giovanni XXIII, A.O. Ospedale di Circolo: Hospital Public Health Practitioner Bergamo, Varese (IT) Areas of work: hospital based Health Technology Assessment, hospital acquired infections, clinical audit 2012-13, 2015 SKILLS • Languages: Italian: MT, English: proficient (C1), Spanish: intermediate (B2), French: intermediate (B1), Chinese: beginner (A1) • Communication skills: from 1999 to 2011, member of various student associations (IFMSA, CUT), from 2013 to 2014, moderator at EU Youth in Action (Erasmus+) trainings, in 2015, third price in BEUC “Healthy & sustanaible food consumers communication Contest” • Organizational skills: from 2009, organization of scientific events (Unimib, ASL LC, ASL MI, EUPHA), from 2011, team-work daily, from 2012, attendance to several certified online courses, from 2012, team-leader for large-scale Vatican events • Social skills: from 1999 to 2012, youth educator and event organizer, from 2005, member of Doctors with Africa CUAMM Lecco, from 2009, active member of the sharing economy (e.g. CouchSurfing, BikeMi, BlaBla car, owdfunding) • Computer skills: working knowledge of Office, Analytica, SPSS, Dismod II, EpiInfo • Cultural skills: from 1996, flute player, in 1998 and 2003, first award in writing competitions • Relevant Memberships: European Public Health Association (EUPHA 2012-current), Young Forum Gastein (YGF 2014-current), ASPHER's Public Health Nutrition Core Competences Expert Group (2017-current), Doctors with Africa CUAMM (2005-current) • Interests: travelling (I lived in 6 different countries and visited over 30), hiking, reading ADDITIONAL INFORMATION • Thesis: 1. column108:
"
Curriculum Vitae

Tony Bliss

Road Safety Management Specialist

Telephone: +64 4 970 9301
Mobile:	 +64 29 7777 044
Email: anthony.bliss@unimelb.edu.au & tonybliss@roadsafetymanagement.com 



Profile

Tony Bliss is an internationally recognized road safety management specialist with extensive experience in the transport, communications and health sectors, and associated global policy research networks. He is currently Honorary Senior Fellow, Urban Transport, Faculty of Architecture, Building and Planning at the University of Melbourne, Australia, and a Director of Road Safety Management Limited, a New Zealand based road safety management consultancy.

In his previous position as the Lead Road Safety Specialist at the World Bank, Washington DC, Tony directed the development, promotion and implementation of multi-sectoral strategies designed to improve road safety in low and middle-income countries, working with World Bank sector teams and global, regional and country partners.

Prior to taking up his position at the World Bank Tony held the position of General Manager, Strategy Division, Land Transport Safety Authority, New Zealand where he helped lead the successful implementation of the National Road Safety Plan 1990 – 2000 and directed the design and preparation of the ongoing national Road Safety Strategy 2010.


Current positions 

2010 – 2016

Honorary Senior Fellow, Urban Transport, The Faculty of Architecture, Building and Planning, The University of Melbourne, Australia

Director, Road Safety Management Limited, Wellington, New Zealand

Member, Expert Panel, Together for Safer Roads, United States of America

Other major roles during this period include:

¬	Global Road Safety Advisor, Monash University Accident Research Centre, Melbourne
¬	Principal Advisor, Commission for Global Road Safety, London
¬	Member, FIA Expert Group, Global Road Safety, Paris
¬	Member, Lancet Group on Transport, Health and Development, London
¬	Global Road Safety Advisor, Global Road Safety Facility, World Bank, Washington DC
Activities during this period include:

•	Delivery of the Eighth Annual Transportation Research and Injury Prevention Programme Lecture, Traffic Safety: The Top Ten Issues, 2016, Indian Institute of Technology, Delhi.

•	Preparation of report on innovative financing opportunities for the FIA High Level Panel for Road Safety, to support achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals targets. 

•	Review of three decades of World Bank Group (WBG) road safety practice to assess country progress, the contribution made by catalytic grant funding to country client engagement and investment, identify strategic goals and priorities for the newly established Transport and ICT Global Practice, and outline related staff development requirements.

•	Participation in panel session, Parallel Session 1, Road Safety Management, 2nd Global High-Level Conference on Road Safety: Time for Results, Brasilia, 2015.

•	Participation in panel session, Children, Cities & the Sustainable Development Goals: Setting the Policy Framework to Secure Healthy Futures, FIA Foundation Forum on Child Health & Urban Mobility, 2nd Global High-Level Conference on Road Safety: Time for Results, Brasilia, 2015.

•	Identification and preparation of a large-scale, multi-sectoral road safety component for the World Bank financed Uttar Pradesh Core Road Network Development Project, India.

•	Provision of strategic support to the Road, Housing and Urban Development Research Center, Islamic Republic of Iran, to assist preparation of an Action Plan to implement the first phase of the Iran Road Safety Strategy 2011 – 2020.

•	Provision of strategic support to the New Zealand Government to Government (G2G) agency, to prepare a study tour and review program supporting the State of Qatar’s national road safety strategy and action plan, under a proposed inter-country cooperation agreement.

•	Delivery of keynote address, Road Safety in the 21st Century, and provision of advisory services to the National Road Safety Forum, Sydney, Australia, 2015.

•	Design and delivery of the Monash University Accident Research Centre (MUARC) VicRoads’ Executive Road Safety Leadership Program, 2015, in partnership with the University of Melbourne, Faculty of Architecture, Building and Planning. 

•	Delivery of 25th Westminster Lecture on Transport Safety, Road Safety in the 21st Century –Public Expectations of Government, Palace of Westminster, London, December 2014.

•	Member of Expert Panel advising the New Zealand Transport Agency on the design and delivery of Signature Projects supporting the implementation of the Safer Journeys road safety strategy Action Plan 2013 – 2015.

•	Preparation of Foreword: Transport for Health: The Global Burden of Disease from Motorized Transport, published by Institute of Health Metrics and Evaluation, the World Bank Group and the Global Road Safety Facility.
 
•	Provision of advisory services to the World Bank Global Road Safety Facility concerning staff training issues, the Multilateral Development Bank Road Safety Initiative, and the design and conduct of a national road safety workshop in Uttar Pradesh, India.

•	Conduct of strategic road safety planning workshop for the District Commanders of the Upper North Island region of New Zealand Police, to review past enforcement performance and prepare strategic directions for the road policing contribution to New Zealand’s Safer Journeys road safety strategy to 2020.

•	Design and coordination of the Monash University Accident Research Centre (MUARC) Road Safety Management Leadership Program, 2012, 2013 & 2014, delivered in partnership with the Melbourne Business School and University of Adelaide’s Centre for Automotive Safety Research. The program integrated leadership theory and practice and road safety science within a change management framework that addressed the themes of adaptive leadership, stakeholder management and power and influence, to identify organizational leadership challenges and the development of action plans to overcome them. 

•	Providing editorial support to the Commission for Global Road Safety’s fourth Make Roads Safe report (Safe Roads for All: A Post-2015 Agenda for Health and Development) and representing the Commission at the report launch in Seoul during Road Safety Week, May 2013; and providing editorial support to the Commission’s third Make Roads Safe report (Time for Action) launched in London, prior to the formal global launch of the Decade of Action for Road Safety 2011 - 2020.

•	Design of the Monash University Accident Research Center (MUARC) Asian Road Safety Innovation Platform designed to mobilize and connect global knowledge with strategic road safety priorities in the Asian region, to generate and leverage regional research and policy-making addressing country road safety priorities through the facilitation of sustained South-South engagement and knowledge sharing.

•	Preparation of guidelines: Improving Global Road Safety: Towards Equitable and Sustainable Development. Guidelines for Country Road Safety Engagement, International Union for Health Promotion and Education (IUHPE), Paris, highlighting innovative features of the World Bank Group (WBG) financed Argentina Road Safety Project and complementing WBG guidelines for the conduct of country road safety management capacity reviews.

•	Delivery of keynote presentations at the Abu Dhabi Road Safety Forum 2013, United Arab Emirates, and The Second Forum of Traffic Safety: National Partnership and Corporate Social Responsibility 2013, Dammam, Saudi Arabia.

•	Presentation on road safety development priorities and participation in AUSAID financed road safety management capacity review workshop in East Java, Indonesia.

•	Preparation and delivery of a training module on international experience with the Safe System approach for the New Zealand Transport Agency’s Safe System in Practice training program, designed to support the implementation of the national Safer Journeys Strategy 2010 – 2020. 

•	Providing advisory services to the New Zealand Ministry of Transport to evaluate the the first Action Plan (2010 – 2012), which guided implementation of the national Safer Journeys Strategy 2010 – 2020, and to assist the preparation of the second Action Plan (2013 – 2015) for ongoing strategy implementation.

•	Design and facilitation of the Multilateral Development Bank Road Safety Training Program at the African Development Bank, Tunis, Tunisia. The five-day program comprised eight thematic modules and was delivered to senior regional transport staff from the World Bank Group and African Development Bank.

•	Preparation of supplementary World Bank Group country guidelines, building on previously developed guidelines, for the conduct of road safety management capacity reviews and the specification of lead agency reforms, investment strategies and Safe System projects.

•	Supporting the participation of the World Bank Global Road Safety Facility in the Bloomberg Philanthropies Road Safety in Ten Countries (RS10) program, including the design and implementation of road safety management capacity reviews and International Road Assessment Programme (iRAP) surveys in China, India and Russia.

•	Preparing World Bank Group resource paper for the National Transport Policy Development Committee in India on long-term road safety priorities for the nation.

•	Contributing to the development of ISO 39001, Road Traffic Safety Management Systems and advising and presenting on its potential application in low and middle-income countries.

•	Specifying a governance framework for a proposed incentive fund seeking donor support to assist the implementation of the Joint Statement on a Shared Approach to Road Safety Management, which specified the priorities of the Multilateral Development Bank Road Safety Initiative launched by the African Development Bank, Asian Development Bank, European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, European Investment Bank, Inter-American Development Bank, Islamic Development Bank and World Bank.

•	Delivery of the Monash University Accident Research Centre (MUARC) Annual Traffic Safety Lecture 2011, Producing Road Safety: The Institutional Dimension.

•	Preparation of an interim report on World Bank Group/China Road Safety Engagement Strategy (with Jeanne Breen and Eric Howard) setting out priorities for innovative interventions, policy reviews, and international cooperation and leadership. 

•	Participating in the CISEV Ibero-American Road Safety Congress (Buenos Aires, Argentina) as Vice President of the Congress Organizing Committee, and making a keynote presentation on the role of the lead agency in road safety.

•	Participating in the Hubei Road Safety Training Center High-Level Forum (Wuhan) and the World Bank Group/China Road Safety Engagement Strategy Launch Forum (Beijing) by making keynote presentations on global road safety trends and promoting debate on related challenges and opportunities for China.

•	Delivery of keynote address, Global Road Safety Issues: Safe System Challenges and Opportunities for Engineering, at the Institution of Transportation Studies Seminar Series, Fall 2010, University of California, Berkeley.
Previous position

2002 – 2010

Lead Road Safety Specialist, Transport Division, Energy Transport and Water Department, Sustainable Development Network, The World Bank, Washington DC, USA

Related roles during this period included:

¬	Convener, Multilateral Development Bank Working Group on Road Infrastructure Safety and related Multilateral Development Bank Road Safety Initiative

¬	Member, International Coordinating Committee, Moscow Ministerial

¬	Member, United Nations Friends of the Decade Committee

¬	Principal Advisor, Commission for Global Road Safety

¬	Member, Advisory Board, European Centre for Injury Prevention

¬	Member, Editorial Committee, ISO 39001, Road Traffic Safety Management Systems

¬	Member, Executive Committee, Global Road Safety Partnership (GRSP)

¬	Member, US Government Committee for the Study of Traffic Safety Lessons from Benchmark Nations, Transportation Research Board

¬	Member, European Conference of Ministers of Transport/International Transport Forum peer review team to assess road safety performance in the Russian Federation


Achievements during this period included:

Developing and implementing new corporate policies and practices to strengthen client and World Bank Group staff road safety management capacity and improve the road safety results of related investment operations, including:

•	Designing, testing and publishing new country guidelines for the conduct of road safety management capacity reviews and the specification of lead agency reforms, investment strategies and Safe System projects;

•	Advising on the application of country guidelines and quality assuring related activities;

•	Evaluating past World Bank Group policies, practices and projects in China;

•	Contributing to the specification of the new World Bank Group transport sector business strategy Safe, Clean and Affordable Transport for Development;

•	Building internal partnerships between the transport and health sectors to integrate World Bank Group investment operations seeking improved road safety results; and

•	Preparing a corporate policy to assure the safety of World Bank Group staff while travelling for work purposes on the high-risk roads of low and middle-income countries.
Advising and supporting country initiatives in all World Bank Group regions (East Asia and Pacific, Europe and Central Asia, Latin America and the Caribbean, Middle East and North Africa, South Asia and Sub-Saharan Africa), including:

•	Assisting the preparation and implementation of country investment operations in a range of low and middle-income countries (e.g. Argentina, Armenia, Bangladesh, Brazil, China, Colombia, Georgia, India, Iran, Kenya, Kosovo, Nigeria, Pakistan, Peru, Russian Federation, Serbia, Thailand and Vietnam); and

•	Peer reviewing country road safety initiatives and providing related advice.


Providing technical support to high-income countries in specific instances, including:

•	Participating in reviews of road safety management capacity in Sweden and Western Australia (with Jeanne Breen and Eric Howard); and

•	Member of US government Committee on Traffic Safety Lessons from Benchmark Nations tasked with identifying road safety strategies that could succeed in the US and assist the realignment of federal road safety priorities.


Directing and shaping global and regional road safety policies, including:

•	Contributing to the preparation of the World Report on Road Traffic Injury Prevention which was launched on World Health Day in 2004 to promote improved road safety as a global development priority; and representing the World Report’s recommendations to successive UN General Assembly technical committees (subsequently addressed by UN General Assembly Resolutions 56/289, 60/5 and 62/244 (Improving global road safety));

•	Providing direction and editorial support for good practice guides addressing key road safety risk factors, to assist the implementation of World Report recommendations;

•	Providing advisory and editorial support to the Global Commission for Road Safety and their global Make Roads Safe campaign reports;

•	Representing the World Bank Group on the Executive Committee of the Global Road Safety Partnership (originally created as a World Bank Business Partners in Development Program to build tripartite partnerships between business, government and civil society);

•	Preparing the management and knowledge transfer chapters for the OECD/International Transport Forum report Towards Zero: Ambitious Road Safety Targets and the Safe System Approach which sets out policies and practices applicable to all countries, irrespective of their current income and performance status; 

•	Providing technical support and a generic road safety management model for the preparation of the new International Organization for Standardization (ISO) 39001 Standard on Road Traffic Safety Management Systems; and

•	Supporting preparatory activities for the First Global Ministerial Conference on Road Safety and assisting the drafting of a comprehensive Global Plan for the proposed Decade of Action for Road Safety 2011 - 2020.
Creating and managing the World Bank Global Road Safety Facility, including:

•	Designing and creating the Facility within the World Bank’s Global Partnership and Programs framework;

•	Negotiating and securing start-up and ongoing donor funding, and preparing related Administration Agreements;

•	Preparing the Facility’s strategic plan and related business plans;

•	Establishing and managing the Facility Implementation Unit;

•	Recruiting and supervising Facility Implementation Unit staff;

•	Recruiting and managing relationships with the Core Advisory Group which comprised eminent international road safety experts;

•	Directing and supervising all Facility grants to global, regional and country recipients;

•	Preparing the first Facility Activities Report which covered its start-up phase operations;

•	Representing the Facility in an internal Quality Assurance Group review of ‘quality at entrance’ and a major independent evaluation of its start-up phase;

•	Managing relationships with members of the Facility Executive Board; 

•	Representing the Facility in global, regional and country events; and

•	Building global and regional partnerships and related tools and programs (see below).


Designing and conducting training and management development programs for World Bank Group staff and clients, including:

•	A three-day road safety management training workshop in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, which brought together high-level officials from nine African countries;

•	A two-day workshop designed to assess national road safety priorities and scope related project investment in Bangladesh, which included staff from the Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology Accident Research Centre, World Bank country office, and national and local government agencies;

•	A one-day workshop for the Executive Director and key staff from the newly created lead road safety agency in Argentina and World Bank country office staff to assist the preparation, design and implementation of a large-scale country investment operation;

•	A three-day regional road safety knowledge management program in Australia, in association with AusAID, which included staff from transport, police and academic institutions in Bangladesh, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Papua New Guinea and Vietnam, and staff from related World Bank country offices;

•	A three-day road safety management training program at the World Bank Group headquarters in Washington DC which hosted road safety experts, client agency staff from 25 countries and related World Bank staff; and

•	Staff training programs as part of the World Bank Group transport sector’s annual Transport Forum and Learning Week events.


Building and sustaining global and regional partnerships, including initiatives with:

•	The International Road Assessment Programme (iRAP), to develop infrastructure safety rating and investment planning tools suited to the road environments in low and middle-income countries;

•	The International Road Traffic Accident Database Group, OECD/ITF, to support peer-to-peer twinning arrangements between high income and low and middle-income countries seeking to strengthen their road safety data management system capacity;

•	The Road Traffic Injuries Research Network, to support the creation and strengthening of local road safety research capacity in low and middle-income countries;

•	The Harvard Initiative for Global Health, to support the development of improved measurement of road traffic deaths and injuries in low and middle-income countries and preparation of related Global Burden of Disease program estimates;

•	The Ibero-American and Caribbean Road Safety Forum, to support a scaled-up focus on road safety in the Latin America and Caribbean region.

•	International Council for Alcohol and Drugs and Traffic Safety (ICADTS), to facilitate the development and implementation of professional development fellowships in alcohol, drugs and traffic safety, to be implemented by professional twinning partnerships between ICADTS member countries and low and middle-income countries. 

•	The International Road Policing Organization (RoadPOL), to develop a police engagement model in partnership with international police leaders designed to improve the governance and operational effectiveness of road safety enforcement in low and middle-income countries, and

•	Seven multilateral development banks (African Development Bank, Asian Development Bank, European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, European Investment Bank, Inter-American Development Bank, Islamic Development Bank and the World Bank), to harmonize country road safety policies and practices, in accordance with the Paris and Accra Declarations.


Presenting and participating in global, regional and national conferences, seminars and workshops, including:

•	UN General Assembly technical and media sessions; global and regional Make Roads Safe conferences; the First Global Ministerial Conference on Road Safety; other global, regional and national road safety conferences; and presentations at leading public health universities: Johns Hopkins, Colombia and Harvard; and

•	The design and conduct of annual half-day workshops on road safety issues and developments in low and middle-income countries, held during the US Transportation Research Board (TRB) Conference in Washington DC.
Past positions


1994 - 2002

General Manager, Strategy Division, Land Transport Safety Authority,
Wellington, New Zealand

Related roles during this period included:

¬	Chairman, National Road Safety Working Group

¬	Chairman, National Road Safety Advisory Group

¬	Chairman, New Zealand Road Safety Programme Review Group

¬	Member, Australasian Road Safety Strategy Panel

¬	Member, International Advisory Committee, Japan Global Road Safety Partnership (GSRP) Committee

¬	Member SUNflower Advisory Panel, advising on a comparative study of the development of road safety in Sweden, the United Kingdom and the Netherlands

¬	Member, Expert Advisory Panel, New Zealand Injury Prevention Strategy

¬	Member, Editorial Committee, Public Sector Journal


Achievements during this period included:

Creating a cohesive divisional environment and building sustainable partnerships within the new Authority and with external agencies and peers which contributed to the achievement of sustained reductions in road deaths and injuries over the ensuing decade.

Specifying the Authority’s corporate vision, mission, goals and strategies and integrated strategic and business planning processes, and producing key corporate documents.

Directing the preparation of the annual New Zealand Road Safety Programme and related funding business case, securing programme funding, and assessing programme performance.

Building and promoting innovative performance management processes to set national road safety targets and budgets, allocate resources and monitor and evaluate results.

Directing the development of a new national Road Safety Strategy 2010 and related performance targets, work programmes and funding requirements.

Strengthening the Authority’s decision support systems, including redeveloping the Authority’s Crash Analysis System and directing the collection of national, regional and local road safety performance data.

Directing a nationwide community development programme to build and strengthen partnerships with local constituencies.

Facilitating and managing the implementation of an intensive national advertising programme designed to support road policing programs targeting unsafe road user behaviors.
Facilitating peer reviews of Police programme efficiency and effectiveness and supporting organisational service delivery capacity.

Directing and coordinating the Authority’s research functions.

Designing and conducting international training courses and workshops on the development and implementation of national strategic plans.

Reviewing international road safety developments and undertaking study tours.

column108: Dr. Antoni Serrano-Blanco had graduated in medicine at the University of Barcelona in 1997, specialist in psychiatry in 2002 at the Spanish Ministry of Health, obtains his PhD in Psychiatry at the University of Barcelona in 2006 and a Master degree at the ESADE Business School in 2015. He currently works as Head of Department at the Acute Psychiatric Unit, the Subacute Psychiatric Unit, the Day Hospital and the Psychiatric Emergency Service of Parc Sanitari St Joan de Déu (PSSJD), Sant Boi de Llobregat, Spain. His research is focused on health services, particularly in mental illness and primary health care. In recent years he has specialized in studies of health economics in the management of depression in primary care, where he developed the thesis and has collaborated on numerous studies. From 2007 to 2017 he leads a Spanish research group at the National Network of Research Activities in Prevention and Health Promotion (redIAPP, www.redIAPP.org). Currently leads a research group at the CIBERESP (Spanish Research Consortium of Epidemiology and Public Health, www.ciberesp.es). As a result of his research activity has published over 85 articles in national and international peer-reviewed journals, has made over 90 oral presentations at national and international conferences. He is currently an associate editor at The Journal of Mental Health Policy and Economics (http://www.icmpe.org/test1/journal/journal.htm) and is a reviewer for several prestigious international scientific journals. On-going projects: 1. Mental Health Training Through Research Network In Europe (MARATONE). 2013 to 2017. Funded by 7MP European Union FP7-PEOPLE-2012-ITN (316795). PI: Ludwig-Maximilians (Universitaet Muenchen). CI: Consorcio CIBER para el área temática de Salud Mental, Fondazione IRCCS Istituto Neurologico Carlo Besta, Instytut Psychiatrii i Neurologii, King's College London, Deutsche Lufthansa AG, London School Of Economics And Political Science (Martin Knapp), National Suicide Research Foundation, Parc Sanitari Sant Joan de Déu (JM Haro, A. Serrano-Blanco, S. Ochoa), Siemens AG, Schweizer Paraplegiker-Forschung AG, Universitaet Leipzig, Oulun Yliopisto. 2. Evaluación económica de una intervención compleja multiriesgo para promover conductas saludables en personas de 45-75 años atendidas en Atención Primaria: estudio Econ-EIRA3 (FISPI15/00519). 2016-2018. PI: A. Serrano. 3. PRE-test-STROKE [Personalizing REperfusion Therapeutic Strategies in Stroke]. (PMP15/00022). 2016-2020. CI: Antoni Serrano-Blanco and Maria Rubio (PSSJD), Israel Fernández-Cadenas from Fundació Docencia i Recerca Mútua de Terrassa (FMT), Antoni Dávalos from Hospital Germans Trias i Pujol (GTH), Jaume Roquer (Hospital del Mar, HdM), Francisco Moniche (IBIS, Hospitales Virgen del Rocío y Macarena, Sevilla), Eva Baldrich (Cibbim-Nanomedicine, VHIR), Jin-Moo Lee (Washington University, St. Louis (WU)), Turgut Tatlisumak (Hospital District of Helsinki and Uusimaa (HU), Finland), Rafa Simó (Diabetes Research Group, VHIR), Xavi Ventura (PROMAX), Jean-Charles Sánchez (ABCDx). 4. CIBERESP (CB16/02/00429). 2016-2020. PI: Antoni Serrano Blanco. 5. A non-interventional post-authorisation safety study (PASS) of vortioxetine in Europe. Multicenter observational study on the cost-effectiveness of long-acting antipsychotics vs oral antipsychotics in patients with schizophrenia. Funded by Mental Health Cluster of catalonia. PI: Lluís San. CI: Antoni Serrano, Miquel Bernardo, Corinne Zara, Enric Àlvarez. 7. Diagnosi de la situació de la salut mental a la comarca d'Alt Penedès. 2016-18. Funded by Diputació de Barcelona. column108:
Ali Shafqat Akanda

Assistant Professor
Civil and Environmental Engineering
University of Rhode Island
1 Lippitt Rd, Bliss Hall 302
Kingston, RI 02881, USA
Telephone: 401-874-7050
Email: akanda@egr.uri.edu

EXPERTISE / INTERESTS
o Understanding the role of large scale hydroclimatology on water-borne disease outbreaks with
special emphasis on Indian Subcontinent, South-East Asia and Sub-Saharan Africa.
o Impact of coastal and terrestrial hydroclimatic variability and change on freshwater availability,
access to safe water and sanitation, food and energy security, and public health.
o Increasing population vulnerability due to climate-water-health nexus in urban areas, especially
coastal megacities of developing countries; issues of scales, risk, and resilience.

(a) Professional Preparation

Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur		Civil Engineering		B.Tech, 1996 
University of Oklahoma, Norman, OK		Civil Engineering		M.S., 1998 
Tufts University, Medford, MA				Water Resources		Ph.D., 2011 

(b) Appointments

Assistant Professor, University of Rhode Island, 2013-present 
Post-Doctoral Associate, University of Maryland, 2013 
Post-Doctoral Scholar, Tufts University, 2011-2012 
Graduate Research Assistant, Tufts University, 2006-2011 
Research Scientist, University of Washington, 2004-2006
Test Development Engineer, Autodesk Inc., 1999-2004
Research Assistant, University of Oklahoma, 1996-1998 

(c) Publications

(i) Relevant Recent Publications (Five)

 Akanda, A.S., Jutla, A.S., Colwell R.R., 2014. Global Diarrhoea Action Plan needs Integrated Climate-based Surveillance. Lancet Global Health, 2(2): e69 - e70.
 Jutla A.S., Akanda A.S., Huq A., Colwell R.R., Islam S. 2013. A water marker monitored by satellites for predicting endemic cholera. Remote Sensing Letters, 4(8): 822-831.
 Akanda A.S., Jutla A.S., Gute D.M., Sack B.R., Alam M., Huq A., Colwell R.R., Islam S. 2013. Population Vulnerability to Biannual Cholera Peaks and Associated Macro-Scale Drivers in the Bengal Delta. Am. J. Trop. Med. Hyg., 89(5), pp. 950959.
 Akanda, A.S. and Hossain, F. 2012. The Climate-Water-Health Nexus in Emerging Megacities. EOS Transactions, 93(37): 353-354.
 Akanda, A.S. 2012. South Asias Water Conundrum: Hydroclimatic and Geopolitical Asymmetry, and Brewing Conflicts in the Eastern Himalayas. Intl J River Basin Management, 10(4): 307-315.

(ii) Other Significant Publications (Five)

 Akanda, A.S., Jutla, A.S., Gute, D.M., Evans, T. and Islam, S. 2012. Reinforcing Cholera Intervention through Prediction aided Prevention. Bull World Health Organ, 90: 243-244.
 Akanda, A.S., Jutla, A.S., de Magny, G.C., Alam, M., Siddique, A.K., Sack, R.B., Huq, A., Colwell,  Jutla, A.S., Akanda, A.S., Islam, S. 2012. Satellite Remote Sensing of Space-Time Plankton Variability in the Bay of Bengal: Connections to Cholera Outbreaks. Remote Sensing of Environment, 123: 196-206.
R.R. and Islam, S. 2011. Hydroclimatic Influences on Seasonal and Spatial Cholera Transmission Cycles: Implications for Public Health Intervention in the Bengal Delta, Water Resources Research, 47, W00H07.
 Jutla, A.S., Akanda, A.S. and Islam, S. 2010. Tracking Cholera in Coastal Regions using Satellite Observations. Journal of American Water Resources Association, 46(4): 651-662.
 Akanda, A.S., Jutla, A.S. and Islam, S. 2009. Dual peak cholera transmission in Bengal Delta: A hydroclimatological explanation, Geophysical Research Letters, 36, L19401.

(d) Synergistic Activities

1. NASA Health and Air Quality: Dr. Akanda is a co-PI in NASA Project A Multi-sensor Remote Sensing Approach to Predict Cholera (NNX15AF71G) where he is focused on developing a cholera and water related diarrheal disease forecasting system in Bangladesh based on hydroclimatic determinants of endemic, epidemic, and mixed-mode cholera transmission and spatiotemporal patterns of population vulnerability in coastal and inland areas.

2. NSF IGERT: Dr. Akanda was a contributor in the conceptualization and preparation of the NSF funded IGERT project titled Water Across Boundaries: Integrating Science, Engineering, Policy and Governance to Resolve World Water Conflicts (0966093). Dr Akanda contributed as an early contributor to the project in the preparation of the proposal and the website AquaPedia, as well as for presentation at the World Water Forum 2009 in Istanbul, Turkey.

3. NIH RC1: Dr. Akanda was active contributor and researcher in the preparation, submission, and execution of the NIH funded challenge grant research project in Effects of Climate Change on Cholera Dynamics and Prediction (1RC1-TW008587-01) under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act 2009. Dr. Akanda was a primary author of the research proposal, and also worked in the project after funding as graduate research assistant and as project consultant.

4. NIH T90: Dr. Akandas doctoral research was supported two years by the NIH Ruth Kirschtein Predoctoral Fellowship for the proposal titled Remote Sensing Detection of Cholera (1T90-DK070117-05). Dr. Akanda carried out his doctoral work on the relationships on large-scale hydroclimatology and cholera outbreaks in the Bengal Delta region, one of the biggest cholera endemic regions using large-scale climate and satellite remote sensing datasets. His doctoral work was the first to identify that the two unique seasonal cholera peaks seen in the Bengal Delta region is influenced by distinct seasonal, spring and fall, hydroclimatic processes.

Biruck Desalegn Yirsaw
                                             Email : yirbd001@mymail.unisa.edu.au/biruck471@yahoo.ca

Australia Work permit	Environmental Research Scientist, Environmental Health Officer, Australia

Capability Statement: 
Biruck has a progressive community environmental health service, academic, research and consultancy experience in environmental health for more than 10 years. Biruck joined Hawassa University in 2003 and served in various capacities. Biruck had also spent as Lecturer, academic commission member and chairperson for Environmental Health Department, Hawassa University for three years. Apart from the academic and research role, Biruck worked as consultant for water, sanitation and hygiene and served for three years as SNNP regional advisory committee member for water, sanitation and hygiene. Biruck has an extensive experience in community survey, project evaluation and delivering community environmental health services in the SNNP region. Prior to his PhD study, Biruck joined Kyoto University as a researcher from 20092011 working on environmental health exposure studies. Biruck Desalegn holds a Bachelor of Science in Environmental Health, a Diploma/Associate Degree in Sanitary Science, a Masters Degree in Environmental Sciences and currently completed his PhD study in Environmental Remediation and Public Health from University of South Australia.

He authored peer-reviewed manuscripts on WASH, environmental health policy, environmental health exposure studies and design of environmental technologies.

Curriculum Vitae

	Translation of questionnaire (STD and HIV on commercial sex workers) from its English version to Amharic Version, Ethiopian Family Guidance Association, Addis Ababa area.

Possui graduação em Serviço Social pela Universidade Católica Dom Bosco (1979), mestrado em demografia pelo CEDEPLAR/UFMG (1997) e doutorado em Demografia pela Universidade Estadual de Campinas (2010). Atualmente é docente da Escola de Saúde Pública ´Dr. Jorge David Nasser´ e coordenadora da RIPSA nos Estados (RIPSA nacional) e da RIPSA-MS/Secretaria de Estado de Saúde de MS. Outros Projetos
________________________________________
2008 - Atual
REDE INTERAGENCIAL DE INFORMAÇÕES PARA A SAÚDE
Descrição: A Iniciativa Regional de Dados Básicos em Saúde tem por objetivo apoiar esforços dos países membros em reunir dados e informações para caracterizar a situação de saúde no continente, bem como tornar esses dados disponíveis ao público em geral. Sua concepção baseia-se na seleção de um conjunto de indicadores, agrupados por categorias, que permite traçar um panorama geral da situação de saúde na Região. O trabalho empreendido tem motivado as esferas nacionais a aperfeiçoar seus sistemas e bases de dados e a produzir e divulgar informações, segundo critérios comuns. Ainda em 1995, o Ministério da Saúde e a Representação da OPAS no Brasil acordaram em cooperar no aperfeiçoamento de informações para a saúde, em alinhamento com a Iniciativa Regional de Dados Básicos em Saúde. Uma avaliação preliminar das experiências realizadas em passado recente indicou, como prioridade estratégica, o estabelecimento de ação interinstitucional capaz de potencializar os recursos disponíveis, e de aperfeiçoar a capacidade de formulação, coordenação, gestão e operacionalização do sistema nacional de informações em saúde, preconizado na Lei Orgânica do SUS. A estratégia proposta baseou-se na criação da Rede Interagencial de Informações para a Saúde (Ripsa), concebida por grupo de trabalho ad hoc no qual estiveram representadas as principais estruturas do Ministério da Saúde, a Opas e instituições-chave da política de informações em saúde no País (IBGE, Abrasco, Faculdade de Saúde Pública da USP e Ipea). O Secretário-Executivo do Ministério coordenou o grupo, com o apoio de um secretariado técnico. A Rede deveria articular entidades representativas dos segmentos técnicos e científicos nacionais envolvidos na produção, análise e disseminação de dados, viabilizando parcerias capazes de propiciar informações úteis ao conhecimento e à compreensão da realidade sanitária brasileira e de suas tendências. Em oficinas de trabalho seguintes, foram definidos os objetivos e estrutura da Rede, a matriz de indicadores, os produtos prioritários e a integração de outras instituições de importância nacional para o sistema de informações. Disponível em: http://www.ripsa.org.br/php/level.php?lang=pt&component=63&item=2 . 
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Outra. 
Integrantes: Angela Maria Marques - Coordenador / Paulo Cézar Rodrigues Martins - Integrante / Hulda Kedma Rodrigues Orenha - Integrante / Ana Lúcia Silva - Integrante / Márcia Regina Martins Alvarenga - Integrante / Cássia Barbosa Reis - Integrante / Larissa 
Domingues Castilho de Arruda - Integrante.

column108:
Curriculum Vitae
CONTACT DETAILS
Name	Andrew Morgan 
Phone	02 9246 0470 (w) 0407 705 436 (m)
Email	Andrew.Morgan@asbestossafety.gov.au 

AWARDS
	Churchill Fellow, 2015: To investigate European Union government responses to reduce mesothelioma 
	Australian Public Service (Comcare) Australian Day Award for Impact, 2012. 

KEY SKILLS 
	Strategic policy negotiation and development; economic impact analysis, and policy implementation 
	Ability to analyse and synthesise data and intelligence to identify trends, patterns, risks and opportunities across short, medium and long term horizons 
	Partnership development and stakeholder engagement 

RECENT EMPLOYMENT HISTORY
Asbestos Safety and Eradication Agency 
Director 
May 2014-Present	The Asbestos Safety and Eradication Agency is an independent Australian Government Agency, responsible for developing a nationally coordinated approach for asbestos management and awareness across public health, workplace health and safety, and environmental issues. I am responsible for designing the agency programme strategy, managing a team of policy and project officers, and developing key relationships across all levels of government and key stakeholders in Australia. 

Key Achievements
	Policy development: Developing the National Strategic Plan for Asbestos Management and Awareness (2014-2018), working with state and territory government representatives, and achieving first ever formal endorsement from all state and territory governments in Australia for this plan.
	Programme management: Developing the agency programme strategy, allocating the programme budget (approx. $3-5 million) and implementing a monitoring system to ensure targets are achieved and budgets are effectively monitored and transparent. 
	Consultation and coordination: Managing the Asbestos Safety and Eradication Council Secretariat function, Ministerial briefs and development and managing two new national committees:
o	the Research Advisory Committee, made up of key public health experts, industry and worker representatives, to identify research priority areas, and oversee the agency research strategy. 
o	the Building, Construction and Demolition Sectors committing to ensure the agencys work is informed by industry and worker representatives.
	Strategic policy: aligning the work of the agency to broader government policy including cutting red tape and the Indigenous Affairs whole-of-government Programmes Framework.
	Managing the agencys Ministerial briefings and working with the Minsters Office  
	Operational management: Managing two teams, negotiating the agencys employment conditions and policy, and serving at the Chair of the agencys audit committee.  

Comcare: Various Positions (2009  April 214)
Senior Project Manager
Regulatory Services

December, 2013 April 2014
	In this role, I was responsible for translating psychological injury prevention best practice in to regulatory strategy, operational goals and projects, and to manage external partnerships.
Achievements:
	Program design, relationship development: Representing Comcare on the Mentally Healthy Workplaces Alliance Project, a collaborative program from government, business, research and community organisations, led by the National Mental Health Commission. I have coordinated engagement with state and territory government, and informed of strategic planning and project delivery. 
	Operational policy and training: Delivery of operation policy and training strategy and support materials for Comcare service delivery staff and WHS inspectors for the psychosocial risk portfolio. 
	Project design and coordination: Leading the design and implementation of a change management campaign, including literature review, compliance tool development and inspection program.

Further contributions: 
	Conducted a review of Comcares five year delivery of projects and programs in mental health promotion and harm prevention, identifying impact, changes in behaviour, gaps and future focus. 
	Coordinated multiple briefing and advice for Senior Executive and Senate Estimates, based on program implementation, emerging issues, trends and environmental scanning.

Assistant Director, Work Health Policy

March 2013  December 2013	
I was responsible for managing Comcares policy and service delivery response to the Parliamentary Inquiry into Workplace Bullying, overseeing development of project planning, costing models and program management framework. 
Achievements: 
	Program design and management: Coordinating Comcares program of work to respond to the Parliamentary Workplace Bullying Inquiry, by aligning the strategy to Comcares 5-year strategic plan, and partnering across the business to develop a single Comcare vision. This includes securing funding and resources through developing a costing model, and external liaison and communication. This work received endorsement from Comcares Deputy CEO and Program Board
	Consultation, representation and liaison: Leading national consultation with state and territory government departments and other government departments, including briefing inter-jurisdictional committees, writing issues papers, and delivering a national workshop with representatives from federal, state and territory stakeholders
	Policy design: Delivering national policy models, based on consultation, for a harmonised approach to workplace bullying prevention policy and interventions, based on analysis of state and territory policy, and national tripartite agreements.
	Commissioning national evaluation survey design project to inform future direction, respond to emerging priorities and identify improvement opportunities for operational strategy and policy approach 
	Procuring external services and consultants to deliver services in research, guidance material and literature reviews. 
	Conference Paper Presentation: Mentally Healthy Workplaces, Safety in Action - The Sydney Safety Conference (2013) 

Assistant Director
Work Health Safety Design

June 2012-March 2013	My role was to design and coordinate delivery of a national regulatory campaign, coordinating policy, service delivery and business intelligence inputs to reduce psychological injury in federal workplaces. This included coordination of a national inspection program, output quality management and senior executive briefings. 

Achievements:
	Project management and strategic planning: Leading a national regulatory camping with intelligence-led design, to change employer behaviours. This included the delivery of 13 national forums in metropolitan and regional areas, national inspections program targeting high risk employers and designing compliance improvement strategies, and evaluating national changes in compliance behaviours. 
	Research, analysis, and issues management: Providing and coordinating briefs for Senior Executive, and Senate Estimates regards Comcares strategy for psychological injury prevention and approach to workplace bullying, including complex data collation and analysis.
	Team management: Remote management of a small team  and building performance improvements identifying support when required.
	The program management approach I developed was endorsed by the General Manager to be adopted by other regulatory campaigns.

Assistant Director, Workplace Relationship Resolution Team 

August 2011  February 2012  
	
Management a team of 6 inspectors to specialising in psychosocial risk factors, and delivering a prevention program. 

Achievements:
	Project management: Management and development of an national bullying safety prevention audit campaign
	External representation and liaison: Negotiating with external agencies senior leadership to undertake collaborative and proactive safety improvement programs 
	Team management and leadership: Leading the team to be recognised with a National team award for Impact through service delivery at Comcares Australia Day Awards; preparing the team for new harmonized legislation through guidance material, conducting training and identifying improvements to the case management system; performance planning and creating learning and development plans in partnership with team members
	
	
EDUCATION & KEY TRAINING 
	Masters of Public Policy and Management Monash University: GPA3.5; WAM 78.2 
	Bachelor of Arts (English and Gender & Cultural Studies) University of Sydney: 2006 
	Career Development Assessment Centre (Senior Executive training), Australian Public Service Commission, 2015). 
	Executive workshops: Managing Regulation, Enforcement and Compliance; Cost Benefit Analysis; Evaluation for Public Sector Managers; Evidence for Decision-Making, and Applying Behavioural Insights, Australian New Zealand School of Government: 2012 - 2015
	Certificate IV Government (Investigations), Diverse Training Concepts: 2010 
	Prince2 Foundation, Tanner James: 2013. 
	Diploma of Project Management, Paladin Risk Management Training Academy, 2015

Ongoing Major Research Projects

1.	Co-investigator in ICMR sponsored study Prevalence of Silent Stroke in Patients with Mitral Stenosis

2.	Centre co-investigator in the HTN-India. It is a single arm study of SmplicityTM Renal Denervation System in Patients with uncontrolled Hypertension  in India.
3.	Principal Investigator in a AIIMS Intramural Research Grant: Association of Vitamin D deficiency with risk of Acute Myocardial Infarction in Indians
4.	National and Centre Principal Investigator of International Heart Failure Registry (INTER-CHF). INTER-CHF is a prospective, international, multicenter registry of approximately 5000 patients with heart failure in Africa, Asia and South America.  The purpose of the registry is to help understand the causes, treatment, outcome and potential barriers to appropriate care for HF in these regions of the world.
5.	Centre co-investigator in the STICHES Trial. STICHES (Surgical Treatment for Ischemic Heart Failure Extended Study) Trial is a NIH sponsored international, multi-centric trial to extend the follow up of STICH trial patients

Major Research Projects (Completed)
1.	Principal Investigator (AIIMS) in the UMPIRE Trial. The UMPIRE Trial is a European Commission, Brussels, Belgium sponsored international, multi-centric trial that aims to investigate the use of fixed dose combination medication polypill compared with usual care in people at high risk of cardiovascular disease.
2.	Centre co-investigator in Trilogy ACS. A trial to compare prasugrel to clopidogrel in patients with acute coronary syndromes.
3.	Centre co-investigator in the STICH Trial. STICH (Surgical Treatment for Ischemic Heart Failure) Trial is a NIH sponsored international, multi-centric trial to assess benefits of surgical intervention if any over medical therapy alone in patients of coronary artery disease and left ventricular dysfunction.

column95: IHME received author form
column108:
Professor Azeem Majeed MD FRCP FRCGP FFPH	
Current positions
	Head of the Department of Primary Care & Public Health, Imperial College London 
	Professor of Primary Care, Imperial College London 
	Consultant in Public Health, Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust, London 
	Family Practitioner, Clapham Manor Health Centre, London 

Education and Qualifications
MB BCh 	UWCM 	1985
MD 	UWCM	1996 
MRCGP	RCGP	1990
MFPH	FPH	1993
FFPH	FPH	2002
FRCGP 	RCGP	2004

Past Employment
Professor  & Senior Lecturer in Public Health & Primary Care at University College London (1999-2004); and Medical Epidemiologist at the UK Office for National Statistics (1997-2004). 5

Achievements
I have extensive experience in the analysis of data from large healthcare databases, administrative databases and health surveys; dealing with record linkage and methodological issues in the analysis of linked data; and ethical and governance issues in the use of data from electronic health records. I have used this expertise to develop programmes of research in health system performance; health inequalities; organisation & delivery of health services; quality improvement in the management of long-term illnesses such as diabetes, cardiovascular disease and respiratory disorders; and the evaluation of new technology and new policy interventions in healthcare.  I have published extensively from my work using data from electronic health records. One example of my applied public health research is work undertaken to improve chronic disease programmes in primary care is the Cutting Out Needless Deaths Using IT (CONDUIT) programme. This programme established electronic registers for cardiovascular disease (BMJ 2000;321:548-50) and diabetes (BMJ 2003;326:1130) in London, and led to major improvements in the organisation of services for these disorders in primary care. These developments have led to significant improvements in chronic disease management, particularly for patients from poorer socio-economic groups and from ethnic minorities, thus helping to address long-standing inequalities in access to healthcare (CMAJ 2007;176:1705-10, PLoS Medicine 2007;12:;e191, Diabetes Care 2011;34: 655-657). This work subsequently led to the development of an information-based comprehensive quality improvement programme for primary care (BMJ 2011;342:c7085). In policy work for national bodies, I have carried our reviews on the secondary uses of primary care data for both the Department of Health (2002) and Association of Public Health Observatories (2005); and an evaluation of the National Congenital Surveillance System for the ONS (Arch Dis Child 2005; 90: F368-73). At the ONS, I also developed systems for monitoring deaths in areas such as dementias and neurodegenerative disorders (BMJ 1998; 317:320-321) and drug poisoning & overdose (PLoS Medicine 2007;4:e105).

Bineyam Taye 
Assistant Professor of Epidemiology and Biostatistics 
Addis Ababa University  	
P.O .box 170584 Addis Ababa, Ethiopia  
Tel: (+251-911-604241(Mobile)
Email: bineymt@gmail.com or bineymt@yahoo.com,  
Gender: Male, Marital status: Married, Date of birth: March 16, 1982 G.C, Place of birth: Dessie , Ethiopia, Nationality: Ethiopian 

SUMMARY
I have served  the government and private higher learning institutions in different capacities as course instructor, guest lecturer, program coordinator, and mentor of students research projects, where I have developed extensive experiences in teaching and mentoring undergraduate and postgraduate students. Specific skills include course materials preparation, implementation and evaluation though application of innovative teaching methodology. In addition, I have developed competency in designing and moderating distance learning modules, and training program evaluation through participatory, qualitative and quantitative techniques.

I have solid experience in conducting researches independently as well as through collaboration with my colleagues and students, and have been successful at disseminating my work in high quality research journals and through scientific presentations around the world.

My academic activities to date demonstrate a strong commitment to the research, teaching and service missions of my institution. In addition, these activities which include collaborative relationships with other departments, institutes, and universities, combined with an active research agenda, innovation in teaching, and a high level of involvement and leadership in community and professional activities, are promise that I will continue to strive for excellence as a  member of academic faculty  in the years to come.      

Educational Background 
PhD in Public Health  (Specialty; Epidemiology and Biostatistics), Addis Ababa University College of Health science, School of public Health, Addis Ababa Ethiopia, expected  2015. 
PhD Thesis Title: The role of Helicobacter pylori infection on growth trajectories, anemia and allergy in an Ethiopian Birth Cohort"  
Master of Public Health (MPH), Addis Ababa University College of Health science, School of public Health, Addis Ababa Ethiopia. October 2006- July 2008.  
Master Thesis Title: The Impact of Malnutrition in Survival of HIV infected Children after Initiation of Antiretroviral Treatment (ART)
Bachelor Degree in medical Laboratory technology (Bsc), Jimma University, Jimma, Ethiopia  2001-2004  
Diploma in Medical laboratory technology, Alemya University, Ethiopia 1997-1999                     

Fellowship 
Medical Education fellowship, two-year merit based fellowship,  FAIMER (Foundation for Advancement of International Medical Education and Research)  Institute , Philadelphia, USA, 2011-2013. Participation includes advance seminars on innovative curriculum designing, effective teaching strategies and students performance assessment, hands-on training on designing and moderating  distance learning (ML-web, blackboard), conducting educational research using  qualitative and quantitative methods.                
         
Short term Trainings/Workshops 
1.Successful completion  "Foundation of Assessment" module, Jun 2013, FAIMER DL and Keele University

3.Training of Trainer (TOT). Clinical training skills for infection preventions July 2008 , Jhpiego( an affiliate of johns Hopkins university ) and CDC- Ethiopia     (certificate)
4.Certificate of successful completion. HIV /AIDS Knowledge update on IP and PITC Jun 2008, Jhpiego( an affiliate of johns Hopkins university ) and CDC- Ethiopia   (certificate)
5.Certificate of successful completion Effective teaching skills training Sept. 2008  by Jhpiego( an affiliate of johns Hopkins university ) and U.S. Centers for Disease Control and prevention (CDC) Ethiopia
6.Certificate of successful completion. Introduction to computerized data management and Epidemiological study. June 2007. by Armauer Hansen institute/ALERT , Ethiopia

Lectured, advised students, prepared tutorial, wrote exam and oversaw group project(i.e. data analysis using statistical software, SPSS, STATA ); was solo responsibility for course contents and overall teaching learning process.       

School of Allied Health Sciences, Addis Ababa University  
?Instructor for undergraduate  and postgraduate allied health sciences students class size 60 and 30 respectively. Developed and directed a full semester based Epidemiology and Biostatistics courses. Lectured, advised students, prepared tutorial, wrote exam and oversaw group project(i.e. data analysis using statistical software, SPSS,STATA ); was solo responsibility for course contents and overall teaching learning process.

Led discussion, laboratory and review sessions to clarify basic statistical tools applied in clinical laboratory. Developed laboratory exercises to illustrate the  course concepts. 

Community teaching Experiences

Rural Community Health Training Program (RCHTP), Addis Ababa University 
RCHTP is a six weeks community based education (CBE) aimed at helping the students acquire first hand experience of working in the community through community diagnosis, and provision of preventive services. Participated as a field supervisor, and provided tutorial on questionnaire development, data entry and data analysis using statistical software package (EPI-info and SPSS), and facilitated field report presentation.

Pre-Service (Pre-Placement ) training program, Addis Ababa University 
Pre-service( pre-placement) training is an innovative short term training program given to  graduating class students  before their placement to actual workplace. This training   aimed to update the knowledge and skills of graduating class students on HIV, TB, and Malaria laboratory diagnostic techniques. Participated as a trainer and taught  "Statistical process control module", and facilitated group discussion.   

Continue professional development,   Ethiopian Medical Laboratory Association.
A one week workshop aimed to equip clinical laboratory professional on basic Antiretroviral treatment (ART) monitoring laboratory tests. Participated as a trainer and taught "Epidemiology of HIV/AIDS module",  and  facilitated group discussion.
   
Workshop on Effective teaching, Jhpiego ( an affiliate of Johns Hopkins university) and U.S. Centers for Disease Control and prevention (CDC) Ethiopia
A 5 days faculty development workshop aimed to equip faculties on different interactive teaching methodologies and students performance assessment. Participated as a trainer and taught "Course Objective Writing  module", and facilitated group discussion.    
       
Faculty development workshop 
A 3 days faculty development workshop aimed to equip faculties on  scientific  literature searching and online communication strategies. Served  as a trainer and taught "Online communication using Google application module", and facilitated hands-on exercise .


Non-Credited Seminar   
A one day hand on workshop aimed to equip postgraduate students on how to design and conduct systematic review and meta-analysis. Served as organizer of the trainer, and developed training  modules, prepared data set for hands-on exercises, delivered lecture and oversaw hand on exercises (i.e. literature searching, data entry and  analysis using statistical Software  STATA  metan commands); was solo responsibility for module contents and overall training process.     

Research Experiences
Public Health, Specialty in Epidemiology, Addis Ababa University, School of Public Health. Jan 2011-to present      
Doctoral thesis research conducted with Prof Gail Davey. Pioneered global health epidemiologist investigating the role of Helicobacter pylori infection on growth trajectories, anemia and allergy in an Ethiopian birth cohort. Resulted in three publications to be submitted to peer reviewed national and international journals. One article stemming from this work, Is Helicobacter Pylori infection inversely associated with  atopy? A systematic review and meta-analysis has recently been published in Clinical and experimental Allergy Journal. (Taye B et al. Clin Exp Allergy, 2014;10(10):12404).              

School of Clinical Laboratory Sciences, Addis Ababa University. 2009-2010
Member of a research team trying to investigate the pathogenesis of Podoconiosis, a neglected tropical disease in Ethiopia. Leaded sub-project aimed to understand the burden of co-morbidity with Podoconiosis and Soil-Transmitted Helminth (STH); Supervised data collection, analyzed data and drafted manuscript for publication. The finding of this study  published ( Taye B et al. PLoS Negl Trop Dis; 2013; 7(3): e2128).

School of Public Health, Addis Ababa University. 2007-2008
Masters' thesis research conducted with Dr Fikrie. Investigated the impact of malnutrition in survival of HIV infected children after initiation of antiretroviral treatment (ART). Participated in data collection, analyzed data and drafted manuscript for publication. The finding of this study  published (Taye B et al. Ethiopian Medical Journal:2010:48:(1):1-10)
      
Department of  Medical Laboratory Sciences, Jimma University. 2003-2004
Honors' thesis research conducted with Dr Yimtu. Investigated the performance of a newly developed  HIV testing kits by comparing with gold standard methods. Performed  laboratory work, analyzed data and drafted manuscript for publication. The finding of this study  published (Taye B et al. Ethiopian Medical Journal: 2006:44 :( 4):363368 )       

Educational research, School of Clinical Laboratory Sciences, Addis Ababa University. 
Participated in educational research projects aimed to improve the quality of  the existing teaching and learning process by collecting students' and instructors' reflections and analyzed data using qualitative and quantitative methods, drafted manuscript and  published the findings in Medical Education Journals as first author (Taye B. WORK EXPERIENCE

RESEARCH EXPERIENCE
Co-Investigator: To assess the role of pegylated albumin (PEG-Albumin) on infarct size in stroke in a mouse model.

Co-Investigator: Critical Appraisal and evaluation of the clinical practice guidelines especially the development and dissemination of CPGs. We have published the appraisal of the CPGs of Infectious Diseases Society of America and presently working on the practice guidelines issued in the field of rheumatology (EULAR), pulmonary and critical care (ACCP), gastroenterology and oncology.

Co-investigator: Phase #3 multi center, open label, single-arm study entitled Tocilizumab efficacy and safety in RA patients after inadequate response to DMARDS or Anti-TNF
      Sponsor: Roche
     Test center: King Fahad medical City, Riyadh, KSA

Co-Investigator: Phase 3 multicenter, double blind, placebo-controlled-randomized, three arm, parallel trial Safety And Efficacy Of Exenatide As Mono Therapy In Drug- Naive Patients  With  Type 2 Diabetes - To compare the effects of exenatide and twice daily placebo with respect to glycemic control, as measured by HbA1c in approximately 258 drug-naive patients treated with diet and exercise. 
Sponsor: Eli Lily & Company, Indianapolis, Indiana, USA
      Test center: Jawaharlal Nehru Medical College, Aligarh Muslim University, India

Co-Investigator: Randomized, multicenter, open-label, two arm, parallel study The Durability Of Twice-Daily Insulin Lispro Low Mixture Compared To Once-Daily Insulin Glargine When Added To Existing Oral Therapy In Patients With Type 2 Diabetes And Inadequate Glycemic Control (The Durable Trial). To compare the safety, efficacy and durability of twice- daily Lispro to once daily  glargine for 30 months in patients with inadequate glycemic control using two oral antihyperglycemic medications. 
Sponsor: Eli Lily & Company, Indianapolis, Indiana, USA
      Test Center  Jawaharlal Nehru Medical, College, Aligarh Muslim University, India

EMPLOYMENT HISTORY

1 Current Position Held: Programme Manager Research and Evaluation (ZIMBABWE NATIONAL FAMILY PLANNING COUNCIL- ZNFPC)
Department: Evaluation and Research Unit (Head Office)
From: October 2010     to: Present Day

Duties:
Research Management
	Development of Funding Proposals for ZNFPC Programs(Community Based, Static Clinic Based and Adolescent Sexual and Reproductive Health Programmes)
	Development of programme-related research proposals
	Designs research instruments when there is a study running
	Participates in the training of research assistants and subsequent field work for that particular  research effort
	Compiles research reports after the processing and analysis of research data
	Participates in collaborative researches with other organizations (ZDHS, RH studies)

Monitoring and Evaluation

	Compiles ZNFPC Quarterly and Annual reports, which will be assessing the performance of the family planning programmes in the given time periods (Results Based Monitoring and Evaluation).
	Participates in the designing of monitoring and evaluation frameworks/plans for specific projects when there is a project running
	Pays regular field visits to project sites to assess progress of and support ZNFPCs research based intervention and routine projects.(Quarterly, Half Year, Yearly and irregularly timed visits)
	Performs secondary analysis of existing survey data as a way of monitoring and evaluating trends in key programme areas and /or indicators on a regular basis.
	Identifies areas requiring further research on the basis of secondary data as need arises
	Participate in the development of the Organizations M&E Plan and Framework. Also participates in the development of the Annual Work plans. 
	Train programme staff on data collection and M&E procedures.
	Reviews Monitoring and Evaluation data collection tools for all ZNFPC programmes (mainly the Adolescent Sexual and Reproductive Health Programme) and checklists for field visits to programme sites.

Period: June 2011 to July 2011

column108:
In AIIMS

	In AIIMS faculty since 1994.
	Has spent more than 15 years as faculty in CRHSP Ballabgarh and have been responsible for many initiatives.
	Currently have research proposals worth 15 Crore in AIIMS including CDC funded Pneumonia Research Platform.
	Have more than 180 publications with an average impact factor of 2.4.
	Member Research Co-ordination Committee and Intramural Research Grant Review Committee

National Level

	Member of the National Steering Committee on Monitoring of National Program for Cancer, Diabetes, CVD and Stroke.
	Member of ICMR Project Review Committee for NCD Division (CVDs, Mental Health, Neurology)
	Advisor, Media Lab Asia, DeITy on use of Information Technology in Public Health
	Member Technical Advisory Committee Global Adult Tobacco Survey 2015.

International Level

	Head, WHO Collaborating Centre for Capacity Development and Research in Community based NCD Prevention and Control.
	Worked on short assignments with WHO/SEARO in the area of NCD prevention and control in the last 10 years. 
	Provided technical assistance to Health Ministries of Bhutan, Nepal, Maldives, East Timor in planning their NCD surveillance programs.  
	Board Member of INDEPTH Network for 2007-2008.
	Member WHO Taskforce To Evaluate Influenza Data To Inform Vaccine Impact And Economic Modeling
	Member WHO Working Group on Influenza Burden Estimation
	Member Global Co-ordination Mechanism for NCD Prevention and Control
